title: The Tragedy of Richard the Third from Mr. William Shakespeares comedies, histories, & tragedies.: Published according to the true originall copies.

characters.name: Berkeley, a gentleman attending on Lady Anne
Sir William Stanley, called also Earl of Derby

Marquis of Dorset, son of Queen Elizabeth

Prince Edward, son of Henry VI

lines.text: NOw is the Winter of our Discontent,
Made glorious Summer by this Son of Yorke:
And all the clouds that lowr'd vpon our house
In the deepe bosome of the Ocean buried.
Now are our browes bound with Victorious Wreathes,
Our bruised armes hung vp for Monuments;
Our sterne Alarums chang'd to merry Meetings;
Our dreadfull Marches, to delightfull Measures.
Grim‑visag'd Warre, hath smooth'd his wrinkled Front:
And now, in stead of mounting Barbed Steeds,
To fright the Soules of fearfull Aduersaries,
He capers nimbly in a Ladies Chamber,
To the lasciuious pleasing of a Lute.
But I, that am not shap'd for sportiue trickes,
Nor made to court an amorous Looking‑glasse:
I, that am Rudely stampt, and want loues Maiesty,
To strut before a wonton ambling Nymph:
I, that am curtail'd of this faire Proportion,
Cheated of Feature by dissembling Nature,
Deform'd, vn‑finish'd, sent before my time
Into this breathing World, scarse halfe made vp,
And that so lamely and vnfashionable,
That dogges barke at me, as I halt by them.
Why I (in this weake piping time of Peace)
Haue no delight to passe away the time,
Vnlesse to see my Shadow in the Sunne,
And descant on mine owne Deformity.
And therefore, since I cannot proue a Louer,
To entertaine these faire well spoken dayes,
I am determined to proue a Villaine,
And hate the idle pleasures of these dayes.
Plots haue I laide, Inductions dangerous,
By drunken Prophesies, Libels, and Dreames,
To set my Brother {% italic: Clarence %} and the King
In deadly hate, the one against the other:
And if King {% italic: Edward %} be as true and iust,
As I am Subtle, False, and Treacherous,
This day should {% italic: Clarence %} closely be mew'd vp:
About a Prophesie, which sayes that G,
Of {% italic: Edwards %} heyres the murtherer shall be.
Diue thoughts downe to my soule, here {% italic: Clarence %} comes.
Brother, good day: What meanes this armed guard
That waites vpon your Grace ?

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: His Maiesty tendring my persons safety,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Hath appointed this Conduct, to conuey me to th'Tower

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vpon what cause?

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Because my name is {% italic: George %}.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Alacke my Lord, that fault is none of yours:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: He should for that commit your Godfathers.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: O belike, his Maiesty hath some intent,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That you should be new Christned in the Tower.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But what's the matter {% italic: Clarence %}, may I know?

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Yea {% italic: Richard %}, when I know: but I protest

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: As yet I do not: But as I can learne,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: He hearkens after Prophesies and Dreames,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And from the Crosse‑row pluckes the letter G:

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And sayes, a Wizard told him, that by G,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: His issue disinherited should be.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And for my name of {% italic: George %} begins with G,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: It followes in his thought, that I am he.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: These (as I learne) and such like toyes as these,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Hath moou'd his Highnesse to commit me now.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Why this it is, when men are rul'd by Women:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: 'Tis not the King that sends you to the Tower,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Lady {% italic: Grey %} his Wife, {% italic: Clarence %} 'tis shee,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That tempts him to this harsh Extremity.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Was it not shee, and that good man of Worship,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Anthony Woodeulle %} her Brother there,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That made him send Lord {% italic: Hastings %} to the Tower?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: From whence this present day he is deliuered?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: We are not safe {% italic: Clarence %}, we are not safe.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: By heauen, I thinke there is no man secure

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: But the Queenes Kindred, and night‑walking Heralds,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: That trudge betwixt the King, and Mistris {% italic: Shore %}.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Heard you not what an humble Suppliant

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Lord {% italic: Hastings %} was, for her deliuery?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Humbly complaining to her Deitie,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Got my Lord Chamberlaine to her libertie.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ile tell you what, I thinke it is our way,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If we will keepe in fauour with the King,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To be her men, and weare her Liuery.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The iealous ore‑worne Widdow, and her selfe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Since that our Brother dub'd them Gentlewomen,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Are mighty Gossips in our Monarchy.

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: I beseech your Graces both to pardon me,

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: His Maiesty hath straightly giuen in charge,

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: That no man shall haue priuate Conference

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: (Of what degree soeuer) with your Brother.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Euen so, and please your Worship {% italic: Brakenbury %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: You may partake of any thing we say:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: We speake no Treason man; We say the King

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is wise and vertuous, and his Noble Queene

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Well strooke in yeares, faire, and not iealious.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: We say, that {% italic: Shores %} Wife hath a pretty Foot,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A cherry Lip, a bonny Eye, a passing pleasing tongue:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And that the Queenes Kindred are made gentle Folkes.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: How say you sir? can you deny all this ?

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: With this (my Lord) my selfe haue nought to

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Naught to do with Mistris {% italic: Shore %}?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I tell thee Fellow, he that doth naught with her

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: (Excepting one) were best to do it secretly alone.

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: What one, my Lord?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Her Husband Knaue, would'st thou betray me?

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: I do beseech your Grace

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: To pardon me, and withall forbeare

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: Your Conference with the Noble Duke.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: We know thy charge {% italic: Brakenbury %}, and wil obey.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: We are the Queenes abiects, and must obey.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Brother farewell, I will vnto the King,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And whatsoe're you will imploy me in,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Were it to call King {% italic: Edwards %} Widdow, Sister,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I will performe it to infranchise you.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Meane time, this deepe disgrace in Brotherhood,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Touches me deeper then you can imagine.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: I know it pleaseth neither of vs well.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I will deliuer you, or else lye for you:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Meane time, haue patience.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: I must perforce: Farewell A stain partially obscures the end of this word..

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Go treade the path that thou shalt ne're return:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Simple plaine {% italic: Clarence %}, I do loue thee so,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That I will shortly send thy Soule to Heauen,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If Heauen will take the present at our hands.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But who comes heere? the new deliuered {% italic: Hastings %}?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Good time of day vnto my gracious Lord.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As much vnto my good Lord Chamberlaine:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Well are you welcome to this open Ayre,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: How hath your Lordship brook'd imprisonment?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: With patience (Noble Lord) as prisoners must:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: But I shall liue (my Lord) to giue them thankes

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: That were the cause of my imprisonment.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: No doubt, no doubt, and so shall {% italic: Clarence %} too,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For they that were your Enemies, are his,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And haue preuail'd as much on him, as you,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: More pitty, that the Eagles should be mew'd,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Whiles Kites and Buzards play at liberty.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What newes abroad?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: No newes so bad abroad, as this at home:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: The King is sickly, weake, and melancholly,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And his Physitians feare him mightily.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now by Iohn, that Newes is bad indeed.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: O he hath kept an euill Diet long,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And ouer‑much consum'd his Royall Person:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: 'Tis very greeuous to be thought vpon.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Where is he, in his bed?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: He is.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Go you before, and I will follow you.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: He cannot liue I hope, and must not dye,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Till {% italic: George %} be pack'd with post‑horse vp to Heauen.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ile in to vrge his hatred more to {% italic: Clarence %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With Lyes well steel'd with weighty Arguments;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And if I faile not in my deepe intent,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %} hath not another day to liue:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which done, God take King {% italic: Edward %} to his mercy,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And leaue the world for me to bussle in.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For then, Ile marry Warwickes yongest daughter.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What though I kill'd her Husband, and her Father,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The readiest way to make the Wench amends,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is to become her Husband, and her Father:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The which will I, not all so much for loue,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As for another secret close intent,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: By marrying her, which I must reach vnto:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But yet I run before my horse to Market:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %} still breathes, {% italic: Edward %} still liues and raignes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: When they are gone, then must I count my gaines.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Set downe, set downe your honourable load,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: If Honor may be shrowded in a Herse;

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Whil'st I a‑while obsequiously lament

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Th'vntimely fall of Vertuous Lancaster.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Poore key‑cold figure of a holy King,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Pale Ashes of the House of Lancaster;

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Thou bloodlesse Remnant of that Royall Blood,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Be it lawfull that I inuocate thy Ghost,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: To heare the Lamentations of poore {% italic: Anne %},

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Wife to thy {% italic: Edward %}, to thy slaughtred Sonne,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Stab'd by the selfesame hand that made these wounds.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Loe, in these windowes that let forth thy life,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: I powre the helplesse Balme of my poore eyes.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: O cursed be the hand that made these holes:

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Cursed the Heart, that had the heart to do it:

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: C ursed the Blood, that let this blood from hence:

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: More direfull hap betide that hated Wretch

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: That makes vs wretched by the death of thee,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Then I can wish to Wolues, to Spiders, Toades,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Or any creeping venom'd thing that liues.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: If euer he haue Childe, Abortiue be it,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Prodigeous, and vntimely brought to light,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Whose vgly and vnnaturall Aspect

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: May fright the hopefull Mother at the view,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: And that be Heyre to his vnhappinesse.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: If euer he haue Wife, let her be made

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: More miserable by the death of him,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Then I am made by my young Lord, and thee.

lines.speaker: Anne.

lines.speaker: Anne.

lines.speaker: Anne.

lines.speaker: Anne.

lines.text: What blacke Magitian coniures vp this Fiend,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vnmanner'd Dogge,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Stand'st thou when I commaund:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Aduance thy Halbert higher then my brest,

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Anne.

lines.speaker: Anne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Sweet Saint, for Charity, be not so curst.

lines.speaker: An.
lines.text: Foule Diuell,

lines.text: If thou delight to view thy heynous deeds,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Foule wrinckled Witch, what mak'st thou in my ( sight?

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: But repetition of what thou hast marr'd,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: That will I make, before I let thee goe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Wert thou not banished, on paine of death?

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: I was: but I doe find more paine in banishment,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Then death can yeeld me here, by my abode.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: A Husband and a Sonne thou ow'st to me,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: And thou a Kingdome; all of you, allegeance:

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: This Sorrow that I haue, right is yours,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: And all the Pleasures you rpe, are mine.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Curse my le Father layd on thee,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: When thou didst Crown his Warlike Brows with Paper,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And with thy scornes drew'st Riuers from his eyes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And then to dry the, gau'st the Duke a Clowt,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Steep'd in the fault e blood of prettie {% italic: Rutland: %}

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: His Curses then, from bitternesse of Soule,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Denounc'd against thee, are all falne vpon thee:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And God, not we, hath plagu'd thy bloody deed.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: So iust is God, to right the innocent.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: O, 'twas the foulest deed to slay that Babe,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And the most mercilesse, that ere was heard of.

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: Tyrants themselues wept when it was reported.

lines.speaker: Dors.
lines.text: No man but prophecied reuenge for it.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: {% italic: Northumberland %}, then present, wept to see it.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: What? were you snarling all before I came,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Ready to catch each other by the throat,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: And turne you all your hatred now on me?

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Did {% italic: Yorkes %} dread Curse preuaile so much with Heauen,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: That {% italic: Henries %} death, my louely {% italic: Edwards %} death,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Their Kingdomes losse, my wofull Banishment,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Should all but answer for that peeuish Brat?

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Can Curses pierce the Clouds, and enter Heauen?

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Why then giue way dull Clouds to my quick Curses.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Though not by Warre, by Surfet dye your King,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: As ours by Murther, to make him a King.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: {% italic: Edward %} thy Sonne, that now is Prince of Wales,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: For {% italic: Edward %} our Sonne, that was Prince of Wales,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Dye in his youth, by like vntimely violence.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Thy selfe a Queene, for me that was a Queene,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Out‑liue thy glory, like my wretched selfe:

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Long may'st thou liue, to wayle thy Childrens death,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: And see another, as I see thee now,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Deck'd in thy Rights, as thou art stall'd in mine.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Long dye thy happie dayes, before thy death,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: And after many length'ned howres of griefe,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Dye neyther Mother, Wife, nor Englands Queene.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: {% italic: Riuers %} and {% italic: Dorset %}, you were standers by,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: And so wast thou, Lord {% italic: Hastings %}, when my Sonne

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Was stab'd with bloody Daggers: God, I pray him,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: That none of you may liue his naturall age,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: But by some vnlook'd accident cut off.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Haue done thy Charme, y u hateful wither'd Hagge.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: And leaue out thee? stay Dog, for y u shalt heare me.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: If Heauen haue any grieuous plague in store,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Exceeding those that I can wish vpon thee,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: O let them keepe it, till thy sinnes be ripe,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: And then hurle downe their indignation

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: On thee, the troubler of the poore Worlds peace.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: The Worme of Conscience still begnaw thy Soule,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Thy Friends suspect for Traytors while thou liu'st,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: And take deepe Traytors for thy dearest Friends:

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: No sleepe close vp that deadly Eye of thine,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Vnlesse it be while some tormenting Dreame

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Affrights thee with a Hell of ougly Deuills.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Thou eluish mark'd, abortiue rooting Hogge,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Thou that wast seal'd in thy Natiuitie

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: The slaue of Nature, and the Sonne of Hell:

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Thou slander of thy heauie Mothers Wombe,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Thou loathed Issue of thy Fathers Loynes,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Thou Ragge of Honor, thou detested‑‑

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Margaret %}.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: {% italic: Richard %}.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ha.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: I call thee not.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I cry thee mercie then: for I did thinke,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That thou hadst call'd me all these bitter names.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Why so I did, but look'd for no reply.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Oh let me make the Period to my Curse.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: 'Tis done by me, and ends in {% italic: Margaret %}.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thus haue you breath'd your Curse against your self.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Poore painted Queen, vain flourish of my fortune,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Why strew'st thou Sugar on that Bottel'd Spider,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Whose deadly Web ensnareth thee about?

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Foole, foole, thou whet'st a Knife to kill thy selfe:

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: The day will come, that thou shalt wish for me,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: To helpe thee curse this poysonous Bunch‑backt Toade.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: False boding Woman, end thy frantick Curse,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Least to thy harme, thou moue our patience.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Foule shame vpon you, you haue all mou'd mine.

lines.speaker: Ri.
lines.text: Were you wel seru'd, you would be taught your duty.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: To serue me well, you all should do me duty,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Teach me to be your Queene, and you my Subiects:

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: O serue me well, and teach your selues that duty.

lines.speaker: Dors.
lines.text: Dispute not with her, shee is lunaticke.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Peace Master Marquesse, you are malapert,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: Your fire‑new stampe of Honor is scarce currant.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: O that your yong Nobility could iudge

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: What 'twere to lose it, and be miserable.

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: They that stand high, haue many blasts to shake them,

lines.speaker: Q. M.
lines.text: And if they fall, they dash themselues to peeces.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Good counsaile marry, learne it, learne it Mar‑

lines.speaker: Dor.
lines.text: It touches you my Lord, as much as me.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, and much more: but I was borne so high:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Our ayerie buildeth in the Cedars top,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And dallies with the winde, and scornes the Sunne.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And turnes the Sun to shade: alas, alas,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Witnesse my Sonne, now in the shade of death,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Whose bright out‑shining beames, thy cloudy wrath

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Hath in eternall darknesse folded vp.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Your ayery buildeth in our ayeries Nest:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: O God that seest it, do not suffer it,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: As it is wonne with blood, lost be it so.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Peace, peace for shame: If not, for Charity.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Vrge neither charity, nor shame to me:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Vncharitably with me haue you dealt,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And shamefully my hopes (by you) are butcher'd.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: My Charity is outrage, Life my shame,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And in that shame, still liue my sorrowes rage.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Haue done, haue done.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: O Princely Buckingham, Ile kisse thy hand,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: In signe of League and amity with thee:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Now faire befall thee, and thy Noble house:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Thy Garments are not spotted with our blood:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Nor thou within the compasse of my curse.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Nor no one heere: for Curses neuer passe

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: The lips of those that breath them in the ayre.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: I will not thinke but they ascend the sky,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And there awake Gods gentle sleeping peace.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: O Buckingham, take heede of yonder dogge:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Looke when he fawnes, he bites; and when he bites,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: His venom tooth will rankle to the death.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Haue not to do with him, beware of him,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Sinne, death, and hell haue set their markes on him,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And all their Ministers attend on him.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What doth she say, my Lord of Buckingham.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Nothing that I respect my gracious Lord.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: What dost thou scorne me

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: For my gentle counsell?

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And sooth the diuell that I warne thee from.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: O but remember this another day:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And say (poore {% italic: Margaret %}) was a Prophetesse:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Liue each of you the subiects to his hate,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And he to yours, and all of you to Gods.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: My haire doth stand an end to heare her curses.

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: And so doth mine, I muse why she's at libertie.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I cannot blame her, by Gods holy mother,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: She hath had too much wrong, and I repent

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My part thereof, that I haue done to her.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: I neuer did her any to my knowledge.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Yet you haue all the vantage of her wrong:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I was too hot, to do somebody good,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That is too cold in thinking of it now:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Marry as for {% italic: Clarence %}, he is well repayed:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: He is frank'd vp to fatting for his paines,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: God pardon them, that are the cause thereof.

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: A vertuous, and a Christian‑like conclusion

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: To pray for them that haue done scath to vs.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So do I euer, being well aduis'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For had I curst now, I had curst my selfe.

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: Madam, his Maiesty doth call for you,

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: And for your Grace, and yours my gracious Lord.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: {% italic: Catesby %} I come, Lords will you go with mee.

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: We wait vpon your Grace.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawle.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The secret Mischeefes that I set abroach,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I lay vnto the greeuous charge of others.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %}, who I indeede haue cast in darknesse,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I do beweepe to many simple Gulles,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Namely to {% italic: Derby, Hastings, Buckingham, %}

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And tell them 'tis the Queene, and her Allies,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That stirre the King against the Duke my Brother,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now they beleeue it, and withall whet me

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To be reueng'd on {% italic: Riuers, Dorset, Grey %}.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But then I sigh, and with a peece of Scripture,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Tell them that God bids vs do good for euill:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And thus I cloath my naked Villanie

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With odde old ends, stolne forth of holy Writ,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And seeme a Saint, when most I play the deuill.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But soft, heere come my Executioners,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: How now my hardy stout resolued Mates,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Are you now going to dispatch this thing?

lines.speaker: Vil.
lines.text: We are my Lord, and come to haue the Warrant,

lines.speaker: Vil.
lines.text: That we may be admitted where he is.

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Well thought vpon, I haue it heare about me:

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: When you haue done, repayre to {% italic: Crosby %} place;

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: But sirs be sodaine in the execution,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Withall obdurate, do not heare him pleade;

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: For {% italic: Clarence %} is well spoken, and perhappes

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: May moue your hearts to pitty, if you marke him.

lines.speaker: Vil.
lines.text: Tut, tut, my Lord, we will not stand to prate,

lines.speaker: Vil.
lines.text: Talkers are no good dooers, be assur'd:

lines.speaker: Vil.
lines.text: We go to vse our hands, and not our tongues.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your eyes drop Mill‑stones, when Fooles eyes

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I like you Lads, about your businesse straight.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Go, go, dispatch.

lines.speaker: Vil.
lines.text: We will my Noble Lord.

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: Why lookes your Grace so heauily to day.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: 0, I haue past a miserable night,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: So full of fearefull Dreames, of vgly sights,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: That as I am a Christian faithfull man,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: I would not spend another such a night

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Though 'twere to buy a world of happy daies:

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: So full of dismall terror was the time.

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: What was your dream my Lord, I pray you tel me

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Me thoughts that I had broken from the Tower,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And was embark'd to crosse to Burgundy,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And in my company my Brother Glouster,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Who from my Cabin tempted me to walke,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Vpon the Hatches: There we look'd toward England,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And cited vp a thousand heauy times,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: During the warres of Yorke and Lancaster

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: That had befalne vs. As we pac'd along

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Vpon the giddy footing of the Hatches,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Me thought that Glouster stumbled, and in falling

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Strooke me (that thought to stay him) ouer‑boord,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Into the tumbling billowes of the maine.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: O Lord, me thought what paine it was to drowne,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: What dreadfull noise of water in mine eares,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: What sights of vgly death within mine eyes.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Me thoughts, I saw a thousand fearfull wrackes:

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: A thousand men that Fishes gnaw'd vpon:

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Wedges of Gold, great Anchors, heapes of Pearle,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Inestimable Stones, vnvalewed Iewels,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: All scattred in the bottome of the Sea,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Some lay in dead‑mens Sculles, and in the holes

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: (As 'twere in scorne of eyes) reflecting Gemmes,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: That woo'd the slimy bottome of the deepe,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And mock'd the dead bones that lay scattred by.

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: Had you such leysure in the time of death

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: To gaze vpon these secrets of the deepe ?

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Me thought I had, and often did I striue

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: To yeeld the Ghost: but still the enuious Flood

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Stop'd in my soule, and would not let it forth

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: To find the empty, vast, and wand'ring ayre:

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: But smother'd it within my panting bulke,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Who almost burst, to belch it in the Sea.

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: Awak'd you not in this sore Agony?

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: No, no, my Dreame was lengthen'd after life.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: O then, began the Tempest to my Soule.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: I past (me thought) the Melancholly Flood,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: With that sowre Ferry‑man which Poets write of,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Vnto the Kingdome of perpetuall Night.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: The first that there did greet my Stranger‑soule,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Was my great Father‑in‑Law, renowned Warwicke,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Who spake alowd: What scourge for Periurie,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Can this darke Monarchy affoord false {% italic: Clarence %}?

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: And so he vanish'd. Then came wand'ring by,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: A Shadow like an Angell, with bright hayre

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Dabbel'd in blood, and he shriek'd out alowd

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %} is come, false, fleeting, periur'd {% italic: Clarence %},

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: That stabb'd me in the field by Tewkesbury:

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Seize on him Furies, take him vnto Torment.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: With that (me thought) a Legion of foule Fiends

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: uiron'd me, and howled in mine eares

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: uch hiddeous cries, that with the very Noise,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: I (trembling) wak'd, and for a season after,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Could not beleeue, but that I was in Hell,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Such terrible Impression made my Dreame.

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: No maruell Lord, though it affrighted you,

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: I am affraid (me thinkes) to heare you tell it.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Ah Keeper, Keeper, I haue done these things

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: (That now giue euidence against my Soule)

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: For {% italic: Edwards %} sake, and see how he requits mee.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: O God! if my deepe prayres cannot appease thee,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: But thou wilt be aueng'd on my misdeeds,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Yet execute thy wrath in me alone:

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: O spare my guiltlesse Wife, and my poore children.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Keeper, I prythee sit by me a‑while,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: My Soule is heauy, and I faine would sleepe.

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: I will my Lord, God giue your Grace good rest.

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: Sorrow breakes Seasons, and reposing houres,

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: Makes the Night Morning, and the Noon‑tide night:

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: Princes haue but their Titles for their Glories,

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: An outward Honor, for an inward Toyle,

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: And for vnfelt Imaginations

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: They often feele a world of restlesse Cares:

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: So that betweene their Titles, and low Name,

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: There's nothing differs, but the outward fame.

lines.speaker: 1. Mur.
lines.text: Ho, who's heere ?

lines.speaker: Bra.
lines.text: What would'st thou Fellow? And how camm'st

lines.text: I would speak with {% italic: Clarence %}, and I came hi­

lines.text: What so breefe?
'Tis better (Sir) then to be tedious:
Let him see our Commission, and talke no more.

Did'st breake that Vow, and with thy treacherous blade,

lines.text: And he would loue me deerely as a childe.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Ah! that Deceit should steale such gentle shape,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And with a vertuous Vizor hide deepe vice.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: He is my sonne, I, and therein my shame,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Yet from my dugges, he drew not this deceit.

lines.speaker: Boy.
lines.text: Thinke you my Vnkle did dissemble Grandam?

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: I Boy.

lines.speaker: Boy.
lines.text: I cannot thinke it. Hearke, what noise is this?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Ah! who shall hinder me to waile and weepe?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To chide my Fortune, and torment my Selfe.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Ile ioyne with blacke dispaire against my Soule,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And to my selfe, become an enemie.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: What meanes this Scene of rude impatience?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To make an act of Tragicke violence.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: {% italic: Edward %} my Lord, thy Sonne, our King is dead.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Why grow the Branches, when the Roote is gone?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Why wither not the leaues that want their sap?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: If you will liue, Lament: if dye, be breefe,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That our swift‑winged Soules may catch the Kings,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Or like obedient Subiects follow him,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To his new Kingdome of nere‑changing night.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Ah so much interest haue in thy sorrow,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: As I had Title in thy Noble Husband:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: I haue bewept a worthy Husbands death,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And liu'd with looking on his Images:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: But now two Mirrors of his Princely semblance,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Are crack'd in pieces, by malignant death,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And I for comfort, haue but one false Glasse,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: That greeues me, when I see my shame in him.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Thou art a Widdow: yet thou art a Mother,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And hast the comfort of thy Children left,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: But death hath snatch'd my Husband from mine Armes,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And pluckt two Crutches from my feeble hands,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %}, and {% italic: Edward %}. O, what cause haue I,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: (Thine being but a moity of my moane)

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: To ouer‑go thy woes, and drowne thy cries.

lines.speaker: Boy.
lines.text: Ah Aunt! you wept not for our Fathers death:

lines.speaker: Boy.
lines.text: How can we ayde you with our Kindred teares?

lines.speaker: Daugh.
lines.text: Our fatherlesse distresse was left vnmoan'd,

lines.speaker: Daugh.
lines.text: Your widdow‑dolour, likewise be vnwept.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Giue me no helpe in Lamentation,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I am not barren to bring forth complaints:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: All Springs reduce their currents to mine eyes,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That I being gouern'd by the waterie Moone,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: May send forth plenteous teares to drowne the World.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Ah, for my Husband, for my deere Lord {% italic: Edward %}.

lines.speaker: Chil.
lines.text: Ah for our Father, for our deere Lord {% italic: Clarence %}.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Alas for both, both mine {% italic: Edward %} and {% italic: Clarence %}.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What stay had I but {% italic: Edward %}, and hee's gone?

lines.speaker: Chil.
lines.text: What stay had we but {% italic: Clarence %}? and he's gone.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: What stayes had I, but they? and they are gone.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Was neuer widdow had so deere a losse.

lines.speaker: Chil.
lines.text: Were neuer Orphans had so deere a losse.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Was neuer Mother had so deere a losse.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Alas! I am the Mother of these Greefes,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Their woes are parcell'd, mine is generall.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: She for an {% italic: Edward %} weepes, and so do I:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: I for a {% italic: Clarence %} weepes, so doth not shee:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: These Babes for {% italic: Clarence %} weepe, so do not they.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Alas! you three, on me threefold distrest:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Power all your teares, I am your sorrowes Nurse,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And I will pamper it with Lamentation.

lines.speaker: Dor.
lines.text: Comfort deere Mother, God is much displeas'd,

lines.speaker: Dor.
lines.text: That you take with vnthankfulnesse his doing.

lines.speaker: Dor.
lines.text: In common worldly things, 'tis call'd vngratefull,

lines.speaker: Dor.
lines.text: With dull vnwillingnesse to repay a debt,

lines.speaker: Dor.
lines.text: Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent:

lines.speaker: Dor.
lines.text: Much more to be thus opposite with heauen,

lines.speaker: Dor.
lines.text: For it requires the Royall debt it lent you.

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Madam, bethinke you like a carefull Mother

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Of the young Prince your sonne: send straight for him,

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Let him be Crown'd, in him your comfort liues.

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Drowne desperate sorrow in dead {% italic: Edwards %} graue,

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: And plant your ioyes in liuing {% italic: Edwards %} Throne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Sister haue comfort, all of vs haue cause

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To waile the dimming of our shining Starre:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But none can helpe our harmes by wayling them.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Madam, my Mother, I do cry you mercie,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I did not see your Grace. Humbly on my knee,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I craue your Blessing.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: God blesse thee, and put meeknes in thy breast,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Loue Charity, Obedience, and true Dutie.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Amen, and make me die a good old man,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That is the butt‑end of a Mothers blessing;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I maruell that her Grace did leaue it out.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: You clowdy‑Princes, & hart‑sorowing‑Peeres,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: That beare this heauie mutuall loade of Moane,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Now cheere each other, in each others Loue:

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Though we haue spent our Haruest of this King,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: We are to reape the Haruest of his Sonne.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: The broken rancour of your high‑swolne hates,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: But lately splinter'd, knit, and ioyn'd together,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Must gently be preseru'd, cherisht, and kept:

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Me seemeth good, that with some little Traine,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Forthwith from Ludlow, the young Prince be set

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Hither to London, to be crown'd our King.

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Why with some little Traine,

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: My Lord of Buckingham?

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Marrie my Lord, least by a multitude,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: The new‑heal'd wound of Malice should breake out,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Which would be so much the more dangerous,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: By how much the estate is greene, and yet vngouern'd.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Where euery Horse beares his commanding Reine,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: And may direct his course as please himselfe,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: As well the feare of harme, as harme apparant,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: In my opinion, ought to be preuented.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I hope the King made peace with all of vs,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And the compact is firme, and true in me.

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: And so in me, and so (I thinke) in all.

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: Yet since it is but greene, it should be put

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: To no apparant likely‑hood of breach,

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: Which haply by much company might be vrg'd:

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: Therefore I say with Noble Buckingham,

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: That it is meete so few should fetch the Prince.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And so say I.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then be it so, and go we to determine

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Who they shall be that strait shall poste to London.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Madam, and you my Sister, will you go

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To giue your censures in this businesse.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: My Lord, who euer iournies to the Prince,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: For God sake let not vs two stay at home:

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: For by the way, Ile sort occasion,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: As Index to the story we late talk'd of,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: To part the Queenes proud Kindred from the Prince.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My other selfe, my Counsailes Consistory,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Oracle, My Prophet, my deere Cosin,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, as a childe, will go by thy direction,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Toward London then, for wee'l not stay behinde.

lines.speaker: 1. Cit.
lines.text: Good morrow Neighbour, whether away so

lines.speaker: 2. Cit.
lines.text: I promise you, I scarsely know my selfe:

lines.speaker: 2. Cit.
lines.text: Heare you the newes abroad?
Yes, that the King is dead.
Ill newes byrlady, seldome comes the better:
I feare, I feare, 'twill proue a giddy world.
Neighbours, God speed.
Giue you good morrow sir.
Doth the newes hold of good king {% italic: Edwards %} death?
I sir, it is too true, God helpe the while.
Then Masters looke to see a troublous world.
No, no, by Gods good grace, his Son shall reigne.
Woe to that Land that's gouern'd by a Childe.
In him there is a hope of Gouernment,
Which in his nonage, counsell vnder him,
And in his full and ripened yeares, himselfe
No doubt shall then, and till then gouerne well.
So stood the State, when {% italic: Henry %} the sixt
Was crown'd in Paris, but at nine months old.
Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot
For then this Land was famously enrich'd
With politike graue Counsell; then the King
Had vertuous Vnkles to protect his Grace.
Why so hath this, both by his Father and Mother.
Better it were they all came by his Father:
Or by his Father there were none at all:
For emulation, who shall now be neerest,
Will touch vs all too neere, if God preuent not.
O full of danger is the Duke of Glouster,
And the Queenes Sons, and Brothers, haught and proud:
And were they to be rul'd, and not to rule,
This sickly Land, might solace as before.
Come, come, we feare the worst: all will be well.
When Clouds are seen, wisemen put on their clokes;
When great leaues fall, then Winter is at hand;
When the Sun sets, who doth not looke for night?
Vntimely stormes, makes men expect a Dearth:
All may be well; but if God sort it so,
'Tis more then we deserue, or I expect.
Truly, the hearts of men are full of feare:
You cannot reason (almost) with a man,
That lookes not heauily, and full of dread.
Before the dayes of Change, still is it so,
By a diuine instinct, mens mindes mistrust
Pursuing danger: as by proofe we see
The Water swell before a boyst'rous storme:
But leaue it all to God. Whither away?
Marry we were sent for to the Iustices.
And so was I: Ile beare you company.

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: Last night I heard they lay at Stony Stratford,

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: And at Northampton they do rest to night:

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: To morrow, or next day, they will be heere.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: I long with all my heart to see the Prince:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: I hope he is much growne since last I saw him.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But I heare no, they say my sonne of Yorke

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Ha's almost ouertane him in his growth.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I Mother, but I would not haue it so.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Why my good Cosin, it is good to grow.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Grandam, one night as we did sit at Supper,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: My Vnkle {% italic: Riuers %} talk'd how I did grow

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: More then my Brother. I, quoth my Vnkle Glouster,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Small Herbes haue grace, great Weeds do grow apace.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: And since, me thinkes I would not grow so fast,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Because sweet Flowres are slow, and Weeds make hast.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: In him that did obiect the same to thee.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: He was the wretched'st thing when he was yong,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: So long a growing, and so leysurely,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: That if his rule were true, he should be gracious.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: And so no doubt he is, my gracious Madam.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: I hope he is, but yet let Mothers doubt.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Now by my troth, if I had beene remembred,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: I could haue giuen my Vnkles Grace, a flout,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: To touch his growth, neerer then he toucht mine.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: How my yong Yorke,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: I prythee let me heare it.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Marry (they say) my Vnkle grew so fast,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: That he could gnaw a crust at two houres old,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: 'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Grandam, this would haue beene a byting Iest.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: I prythee pretty Yorke, who told thee this?

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Grandam, his Nursse.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: His Nurse? why she was dead, ere y u wast borne.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: lf 'twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: A parlous Boy: go too, you are too shrew'd.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Good Madam, be not angry with the Childe.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Pitchers haue eares.

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: Heere comes a Messenger: What Newes?

lines.speaker: Mes.
lines.text: Such newes my Lord, as greeues me to report,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: How doth the Prince?

lines.speaker: Mes.
lines.text: Well Madam, and in health.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: What is thy Newes ?

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Lord {% italic: Riuers %}, and Lord {% italic: Grey %},

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Are sent to Pomfret, and with them,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Thomas Vaughan %}, Prisoners.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Who hath committed them?

lines.speaker: Mes.
lines.text: The Mighty Dukes, {% italic: Glouster %} and {% italic: Buckingham %}.

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: For what offence?

lines.speaker: Mes.
lines.text: The summe of all I can, I haue disclos'd:

lines.speaker: Mes.
lines.text: Why, or for what, the Nobles were committed,

lines.speaker: Mes.
lines.text: Is all vnknowne to me, my gracious Lord.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Aye me! I see the ruine of my House:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The Tyger now hath seiz'd the gentle Hinde,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Insulting Tiranny beginnes to Iutt

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Vpon the innocent and awelesse Throne:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Welcome Destruction, Blood, and Massacre,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I see (as in a Map) the end of all.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Accursed, and vnquiet wrangling dayes,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: How many of you haue mine eyes beheld?

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: My Husband lost his life, to get the Crowne,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And often vp and downe my sonnes were tost

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: For me to ioy, and weepe, their gaine and losse.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And being seated, and Domesticke broyles

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Cleane ouer‑blowne, themselues the Conquerors,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Make warre vpon themselues, Brother to Brother;

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Blood to blood, selfe against selfe: O prepostorous

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And franticke outrage, end thy damned spleene,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Or let me dye, to looke on earth no more.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Come, come my Boy, we will to Sanctuary.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Madam, farwell.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Stay, I will go with you.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: You haue no cause.

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: My gracious Lady go,

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: And thether beare your Treasure and your Goodes,

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: For my part, Ile resigne vnto your Grace

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: The Seale I keepe, and so betide to me,

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: As well I tender you, and all of yours.

lines.speaker: Arch.
lines.text: Go, Ile conduct you to the Sanctuary.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Welcome sweete Prince to London,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: To your Chamber.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Welcome deere Cosin, my thoughts Soueraign

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The wearie way hath made you Melancholly.

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: No Vnkle, but our crosses on the way,

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: Haue made it tedious, wearisome, and heauie.

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: I want more Vnkles heere to welcome me.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Sweet Prince, the vntainted vertue of your yeers

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Hath not yet diu'd into the Worlds deceit:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: No more can you distinguish of a man,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then of his outward shew, which God he knowes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Seldome or neuer iumpeth with the heart.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Those Vnkles which you want, were dangerous:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your Grace attended to their Sugred words,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But look'd not on the poyson of their hearts:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: God keepe you from them, and from such false Friends.

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: God keepe me from false Friends,

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: But they were none.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My lord, the Maior of London comes to greet

lines.speaker: Lo. Maior.
lines.text: God blesse your Grace, with health and

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: I thanke you, good my Lord, and thank you all:

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: I thought my Mother, and my Brother {% italic: Yorke %},

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: Would long, ere this, haue met vs on the way.

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: Fie, what a Slug is {% italic: Hastings %}, that he comes not

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: To tell vs, whether they will come, or no.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And in good time, heere comes the sweating

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Welcome, my Lord: what, will our Mother ?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: On what occasion God he knowes, not I;

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: The Queene your Mother, and your Brother {% italic: Yorke %},

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Haue taken Sanctuarie: The tender Prince

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Would faine haue come with me, to meet your Grace,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: But by his Mother was perforce with‑held.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Fie, what an indirect and peeuish course

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Is this of hers? Lord Cardinall, will your Grace

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Perswade the Queene, to send the Duke of Yorke

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Vnto his Princely Brother presently?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: If she denie, Lord {% italic: Hastings %} goe with him,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And from her iealous Armes pluck him perforce.

lines.speaker: Card.
lines.text: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weake Oratorie

lines.speaker: Card.
lines.text: Can from his Mother winne the Duke of Yorke,

lines.speaker: Card.
lines.text: Anon expect him here: but if she be obdurate

lines.speaker: Card.
lines.text: To milde entreaties, God forbid

lines.speaker: Card.
lines.text: We should infringe the holy Priuiledge

lines.speaker: Card.
lines.text: Of blessed Sanctuarie: not for all this Land,

lines.speaker: Card.
lines.text: Would I be guiltie of so great a sinne.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: You are too sencelesse obstinate, my Lord,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Too ceremonious, and traditionall.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Weigh it but with the grossenesse of this Age,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: You breake not Sanctuarie, in seizing him:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: The benefit thereof is alwayes granted

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To those, whose dealings haue deseru'd the place,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And those who haue the wit to clayme the place:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: This Prince hath neyther claym'd it, nor deseru'd it,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot haue it.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Then taking him from thence, that is not there,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: You breake no Priuiledge, nor Charter there:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Oft haue I heard of Sanctuarie men,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But Sanctuarie children, ne're till now.

lines.speaker: Card.
lines.text: My Lord, you shall o're‑rule my mind for once.

lines.speaker: Card.
lines.text: Come on, Lord {% italic: Hastings %}, will you goe with me?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I goe, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Good Lords, make all the speedie hast you may.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Say, Vnckle {% italic: Glocester %}, if our Brother come,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Where shall we soiourne, till our Coronation?

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Where it think'st best vnto your Royall selfe.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: If I may counsaile you, some day or two

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Your Highnesse shall repose you at the Tower:

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: For your best health, and recreation.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: I doe not like the Tower, of any place:

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Did {% italic: Iulius Cæsar %} build that place, my Lord?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: He did, my gracious Lord, begin that place,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Which since, succeeding Ages haue re‑edify'd.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Is it vpon record? or else reported

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Successiuely from age to age, he built it?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Vpon record, my gracious Lord.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: But say, my Lord, it were not registred,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Me thinkes the truth should liue from age to age,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: As 'twere retayl'd to all posteritie,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Euen to the generall ending day.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: So wise, so young, they say doe neuer liue long.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: What say you, Vnckle?

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: I say, without Characters, Fame liues long,

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Thus, like the formall Vice, Iniquitie,

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: I morallize two meanings in one word.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: That {% italic: Iulius Cæsar %} was a famous man,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: With what his Valour did enrich his Wit,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: His Wit set downe, to make his Valour liue:

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Death makes no Conquest of his Conqueror,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: For now he liues in Fame, though not in Life.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Ile tell you what, my Cousin {% italic: Buckingham %}.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: What, my gracious Lord?

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: And if I liue vntill I be a man,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Ile win our ancient Right in France againe,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Or dye a Souldier, as I liu'd a King.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Short Summers lightly haue a forward Spring.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Now in good time, heere comes the Duke of

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: {% italic: Richard %} of Yorke, how fares our Noble Bro­

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Well, my deare Lord, so must I call you now.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: I, Brother, to our griefe, as it is yours:

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Too late he dy'd, that might haue kept that Title,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Which by his death hath lost much Maiestie.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: How fares our Cousin, Noble Lord of Yorke?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I thanke you, gentle Vnckle. O my Lord,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: You said, that idle Weeds are fast in growth:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: The Prince, my Brother, hath out‑growne me farre.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: He hath, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And therefore is he idle?

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Oh my faire Cousin, I must not say so.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Then he is more beholding to you, then I.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: He may command me as my Soueraigne,

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: But you haue power in me, as in a Kinsman.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I pray you, Vnckle, giue me this Dagger.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: My Dagger, little Cousin? with all my heart.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: A Begger, Brother ?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Of my kind Vnckle, that I know will giue,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And being but a Toy, which is no griefe to giue.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: A greater gift then that, Ile giue my Cousin.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: A greater gift? O, that's the Sword to it.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: I, gentle Cousin, were it light enough.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: O then I see, you will part but with light gifts,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: In weightier things you'le say a Begger nay.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: It is too weightie for your Grace to weare.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I weigh it lightly, were it heauier.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: What, would you haue my Weapon, little Lord?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I would that I might thanke you, as, as, you

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: How?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Little.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: My Lord of Yorke will still be crosse in talke:

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Vnckle, your Grace knowes how to beare with him.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: You meane to beare me, not to beare with me:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Vnckle, my Brother mockes both you and me,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Because that I am little, like an Ape,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: He thinkes that you should beare me on your shoulders.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: With what a sharpe prouided wit he reasons:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To mittigate the scorne he giues his Vnckle,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: He prettily and aptly taunts himselfe:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: So cunning, and so young, is wonderfull.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: My Lord, wilt please you passe along?

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: My selfe, and my good Cousin {% italic: Buckingham %},

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Will to your Mother, to entreat of her

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: To meet you at the Tower, and welcome you.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: What, will you goe vnto the Tower, my Lord?

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: My Lord Protector will haue it so.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I shall not sleepe in quiet at the Tower.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Why, what should you feare ?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Marry, my Vnckle {% italic: Clarence %} angry Ghost:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: My Grandam told me he was murther'd there.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: I feare no Vnckles dead.

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Nor none that liue, I hope.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: And if they liue, I hope I need not feare.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: But come my Lord: and with a heauie heart,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Thinking on them, goe I vnto the Tower.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Thinke you, my Lord, this little prating {% italic: Yorke %}

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Was not incensed by his subtile Mother,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To taunt and scorne you thus opprobriously?

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: No doubt, no doubt: Oh 'tis a perillous Boy,

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Bold, quicke, ingenious, forward, capable:

lines.speaker: Glo.
lines.text: Hee is all the Mothers, from the top to toe.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Well, let them rest: Come hither {% italic: Catesby %},

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Thou art sworne as deepely to effect what we intend,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: As closely to conceale what we impart:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Thou know'st our reasons vrg'd vpon the way.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: What think'st thou? is it not an easie matter,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To make {% italic: William %} Lord {% italic: Hastings %} of our minde,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: For the installment of this Noble Duke

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: In the Seat Royall of this famous Ile?

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: He for his fathers sake so loues the Prince,

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: That he will not be wonne to ought against him.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: What think'st thou then of {% italic: Stanley %}? Will

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: Hee will doe all in all as {% italic: Hastings %} doth.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Well then, no more but this:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Goe gentle {% italic: Catesby %}, and as it were farre off,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Sound thou Lord {% italic: Hastings %},

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: How he doth stand affected to our purpose,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And summon him to morrow to the Tower,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To sit about the Coronation.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: If thou do'st finde him tractable to vs,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Encourage him, and tell him all our reasons:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: If he be leaden, ycie, cold, vnwilling,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Be thou so too, and so breake off the talke,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And giue vs notice of his inclination:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: For we to morrow hold diuided Councels,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Wherein thy selfe shalt highly be employ'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Commend me to Lord {% italic: William: %} tell him {% italic: Catesby %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: His ancient Knot of dangerous Aduersaries

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To morrow are let blood at Pomfret Castle,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And bid my Lord, for ioy of this good newes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Giue Mistresse {% italic: Shore %} one gentle Kisse the more.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Good {% italic: Catesby %}, goe effect this businesse soundly.

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: My good Lords both, with all the heed I can.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shall we heare from you, {% italic: Catesby %}, ere we sleepe?

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: You shall, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: At {% italic: Crosby %} House, there shall you find vs both.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Now, my Lord,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: What shall wee doe, if wee perceiue

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Lord {% italic: Hastings %} will not yeeld to our Complots?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Chop off his Head:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Something wee will determine:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And looke when I am King, clayme thou of me

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Earledome of Hereford, and all the moueables

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Whereof the King, my Brother, was possest.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Ile clayme that promise at your Graces hand.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And looke to haue it yeelded with all kindnesse.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Come, let vs suppe betimes, that afterwards

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Wee may digest our complots in some forme.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: My Lord, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Who knockes ?

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: One from the Lord {% italic: Stanley %}.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: What is't a Clocke?

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Vpon the stroke of foure.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Cannot my Lord {% italic: Stanley %} sleepe these tedious

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: So it appeares, by that I haue to say:

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: First, he commends him to your Noble selfe.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: What then?

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Then certifies your Lordship, that this Night

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: He dreamt, the Bore had rased off his Helme:

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Besides, he sayes there are two Councels kept;

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: And that may be determin'd at the one,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Which may make you and him to rue at th'other.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Therefore he sends to know your Lordships pleasure,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: If you will presently take Horse with him,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: And with all speed post with him toward the North,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: To shun the danger that his Soule diuines.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Goe fellow, goe, returne vnto thy Lord,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Bid him not feare the seperated Councell:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: His Honor and my selfe are at the one,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And at the other, is my good friend {% italic: Catesby %};

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Where nothing can proceede, that toucheth vs,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Whereof I shall not haue intelligence:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Tell him his Feares are shallow, without instance.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And for his Dreames, I wonder hee's so simple,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: To trust the mock'ry of vnquiet slumbers.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: To flye the Bore, before the Bore pursues,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Were to incense the Bore to follow vs,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And make pursuit, where he did meane no chase.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Goe, bid thy Master rise, and come to me,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And we will both together to the Tower,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Where he shall see the Bore will vse vs kindly.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Ile goe, my Lord, and tell him what you say.

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: Many good morrowes to my Noble Lord.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Good morrow {% italic: Catesby %}, you are early stirring:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: What newes, what newes, in this our tott'ring State?

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: It is a reeling World indeed, my Lord:

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: And I beleeue will neuer stand vpright,

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: Till {% italic: Richard %} weare the Garland of the Realme.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: How weare the Garland?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Doest thou meane the Crowne?

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: I, my good Lord.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Ile haue this Crown of mine cut frō my shoulders,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Before Ile see the Crowne so foule mis‑plac'd:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: But canst thou guesse, that he doth ayme at it?

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: I, on my life, and hopes to find you forward,

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: Vpon his partie, for the gaine thereof:

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: And thereupon he sends you this good newes,

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: That this same very day your enemies,

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: The Kindred of the Queene, must dye at Pomfret.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Indeed I am no mourner for that newes,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Because they haue beene still my aduersaries:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: But, that Ile giue my voice on {% italic: Richards %} side,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: To barre my Masters Heires in true Descent,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: God knowes I will not doe it, to the death.

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: God keepe your Lordship in that gracious

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: But I shall laugh at this a twelue‑month hence,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: That they which brought me in my Masters hate,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I liue to looke vpon their Tragedie.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Well {% italic: Catesby %}, ere a fort‑night make me older,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Ile send some packing, that yet thinke not on't.

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: 'Tis a vile thing to dye, my gracious Lord,

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: When men are vnprepar'd, and looke not for it.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: O monstrous, monstrous! and so falls it out

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: With {% italic: Riuers, Vaughan, Grey: %} and so 'twill doe

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: With some men else, that thinke themselues as safe

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: As thou and I, who (as thou know'st) are deare

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: To Princely {% italic: Richard %}, and to {% italic: Buckingham %}.

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: The Princes both make high account of you,

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: For they account his Head vpon the Bridge.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I know they doe, and I haue well deseru'd it.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Come on, come on, where is your Bore‑speare man?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Feare you the Bore, and goe so vnprouided?

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: My Lord good morrow, good morrow {% italic: Catesby: %}

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: You may ieast on, but by the holy Rood,

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: I doe not like these seuerall Councels, I.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: My Lord, I hold my Life as deare as yours,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And neuer in my dayes, I doe protest,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Was it so precious to me, as 'tis now:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Thinke you, but that I know our state secure,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I would be so triumphant as I am?

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: The Lords at Pomfret, whē they rode from London,

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: Were iocund, and suppos'd their states were sure,

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: And they indeed had no cause to mistrust:

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: But yet you see, how soone the Day o're‑cast.

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: This sudden stab of Rancour I misdoubt:

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: Pray God (I say) I proue a needlesse Coward.

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: What, shall we toward the Tower? the day is spent.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Come, come, haue with you:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Wot you what, my Lord,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: To day the Lords you talke of, are beheaded.

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: They, for their truth, might better wear their Heads,

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: Then some that haue accus'd them, weare their Hats.

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: But come, my Lord, let's away.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Goe on before, Ile talke with this good fellow.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: How now, Sirrha? how goes the World with thee?

lines.speaker: Purs.
lines.text: The better, that your Lordship please to aske.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I tell thee man, 'tis better with me now,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Then when thou met'st me last, where now we meet:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Then was I going Prisoner to the Tower,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: By the suggestion of the Queenes Allyes.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: But now I tell thee (keepe it to thy selfe)

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: This day those Enemies are put to death,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And I in better state then ere I was.

lines.speaker: Purs.
lines.text: God hold it, to your Honors good content.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Gramercie fellow: there, drinke that for me.

lines.speaker: Purs.
lines.text: I thanke your Honor.

lines.speaker: Priest.
lines.text: Well met, my Lord, I am glad to see your Ho­

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I thanke thee, good Sir {% italic: Iohn %}, with all my heart.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I am in your debt, for your last Exercise:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Come the next Sabboth, and I will content you.

lines.speaker: Priest.
lines.text: Ile wait vpon your Lordship.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: What, talking with a Priest, Lord Chamberlaine?

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Your friends at Pomfret, they doe need the Priest,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Your Honor hath no shriuing worke in hand.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Good faith, and when I met this holy man,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: The men you talke of, came into my minde.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: What, goe you toward the Tower?

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: I doe, my Lord, but long I cannot stay there:

lines.speaker: Buc.
