lines.text: I shall returne before your Lordship, thence.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Nay like enough, for I stay Dinner there.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: And Supper too, although thou know'st it not.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Come, will you goe?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Ile wait vpon your Lordship.

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Richard Ratcliffe %}, let me tell thee this,

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: To day shalt thou behold a Subiect die,

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: For Truth, for Dutie, and for Loyaltie.

lines.speaker: Grey.
lines.text: God blesse the Prince from all the Pack of you,

lines.speaker: Grey.
lines.text: A Knot you are, of damned Blood‑suckers.

lines.speaker: Vaugh.
lines.text: You liue, that shall cry woe for this heere­

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: Dispatch, the limit of your Liues is out.

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody Prison!

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Fatall and ominous to Noble Peeres:

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Within the guiltie Closure of thy Walls,

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: {% italic: Richard %} the Second here was hackt to death:

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: And for more slander to thy dismall Seat,

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Wee giue to thee our guiltlesse blood to drinke.

lines.speaker: Grey.
lines.text: Now {% italic: Margarets %} Curse is falne vpon our Heads,

lines.speaker: Grey.
lines.text: When shee exclaim'd on {% italic: Hastings %}, you, and I,

lines.speaker: Grey.
lines.text: For standing by, when {% italic: Richard %} stab'd her Sonne.

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Then curs'd shee {% italic: Richard %},

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Then curs'd shee {% italic: Buckingham %},

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Then curs'd shee {% italic: Hastings %}. Oh remember God,

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: To heare her prayer for them, as now for vs:

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: And for my Sister, and her Princely Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Be satisfy'd, deare God, with our true blood,

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Which, as thou know'st, vniustly must be spilt.

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: Make haste, the houre of death is expiate.

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Come {% italic: Grey %}, come {% italic: Vaughan %}, let vs here embrace.

lines.speaker: Riuers.
lines.text: Farewell, vntill we meet againe in Heauen.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Now Noble Peeres, the cause why we are met,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Is to determine of the Coronation:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: In Gods Name speake, when is the Royall day?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Is all things ready for the Royall time?

lines.speaker: Darb.
lines.text: It is, and wants but nomination.

lines.speaker: Ely.
lines.text: To morrow then I iudge a happie day.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Who knowes the Lord Protectors mind herein?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Who is most inward with the Noble Duke?

lines.speaker: Ely.
lines.text: Your Grace, we thinke, should soonest know his

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: We know each others Faces: for our Hearts,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: He knowes no more of mine, then I of yours,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Or I of his, my Lord, then you of mine:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Lord {% italic: Hastings %}, you and he are neere in loue.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I thanke his Grace, I know he loues me well:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: But for his purpose in the Coronation,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I haue not sounded him, nor he deliuer'd

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: His gracious pleasure any way therein:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: But you, my Honorable Lords, may name the time,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And in the Dukes behalfe Ile giue my Voice,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Which I presume hee'le take in gentle part.

lines.speaker: Ely.
lines.text: In happie time, here comes the Duke himselfe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Noble Lords, and Cousins all, good morrow:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I haue beene long a sleeper: but I trust,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My absence doth neglect no great designe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which by my presence might haue beene concluded.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Had you not come vpon your Q my Lord,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: {% italic: William %}, Lord {% italic: Hastings %}, had pronounc'd your part;

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: I meane your Voice, for Crowning of the King.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then my Lord {% italic: Hastings %}, no man might be bolder,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: His Lordship knowes me well, and loues me well.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Lord of Ely, when I was last in Holborne,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I saw good Strawberries in your Garden there,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I doe beseech you, send for some of them.

lines.speaker: Ely.
lines.text: Mary and will, my Lord, with all my heart.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Catesby %} hath sounded {% italic: Hastings %} in our businesse,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And findes the testie Gentleman so hot,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That he will lose his Head, ere giue consent

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: His Masters Child, as worshipfully he tearmes it,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shall lose the Royaltie of Englands Throne.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Withdraw your selfe a while, Ile goe with you.

lines.speaker: Darb.
lines.text: We haue not yet set downe this day of Triumph:

lines.speaker: Darb.
lines.text: To morrow, in my iudgement, is too sudden,

lines.speaker: Darb.
lines.text: For I my selfe am not so well prouided,

lines.speaker: Darb.
lines.text: As else I would be, were the day prolong'd.

lines.speaker: Ely.
lines.text: Where is my Lord, the Duke of Gloster?

lines.speaker: Ely.
lines.text: I haue sent for these Strawberries.

lines.speaker: Ha.
lines.text: His Grace looks chearfully & smooth this morning,

lines.speaker: Ha.
lines.text: There's some conceit or other likes him well,

lines.speaker: Ha.
lines.text: When that he bids good morrow with such spirit.

lines.speaker: Ha.
lines.text: I thinke there's neuer a man in Christendome

lines.speaker: Ha.
lines.text: Can lesser hide his loue, or hate, then hee,

lines.speaker: Ha.
lines.text: For by his Face straight shall you know his Heart.

lines.speaker: Darb.
lines.text: What of his Heart perceiue you in his Face,

lines.speaker: Darb.
lines.text: By any liuelyhood he shew'd to day?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Mary, that with no man here he is offended:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: For were he, he had shewne it in his Lookes.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I pray you all, tell me what they deserue,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That doe conspire my death with diuellish Plots

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of damned Witchcraft, and that haue preuail'd

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vpon my Body with their Hellish Charmes.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: The tender loue I beare your Grace, my Lord,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Makes me most forward, in this Princely presence,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: To doome th'Offendors, whosoe're they be:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I say, my Lord, they haue deserued death.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then be your eyes the witnesse of their euill.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Looke how I am bewitch'd: behold, mine Arme

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is like a blasted Sapling, wither'd vp:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And this is {% italic: Edwards %} Wife, that monstrous Witch,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Consorted with that Harlot, Strumpet {% italic: Shore %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That by their Witchcraft thus haue marked me.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: If they haue done this deed, my Noble Lord.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If? thou Protector of this damned Strumpet,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Talk'st thou to me of Ifs: thou art a Traytor,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Off with his Head; now by Saint {% italic: Paul %} I sweare,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I will not dine, vntill I see the same.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Louell %} and {% italic: Ratcliffe %}, looke that it be done:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The rest that loue me, rise, and follow me.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Woe, woe for England, not a whit for me,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: For I, too fond, might haue preuented this:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: {% italic: Stanley %} did dreame, the Bore did rowse our Helmes,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And I did scorne it, and disdaine to flye:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Three times to day my Foot‑Cloth‑Horse did stumble,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And started, when he look'd vpon the Tower,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: As loth to beare me to the slaughter‑house.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: O now I need the Priest, that spake to me:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I now repent I told the Pursuiuant,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: As too triumphing, how mine Enemies

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: To day at Pomfret bloodily were butcher'd,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And I my selfe secure, in grace and fauour.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Oh {% italic: Margaret, Margaret %}, now thy heauie Curse

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Is lighted on poore {% italic: Hastings %} wretched Head.

lines.speaker: Ra.
lines.text: Come, come, dispatch, the Duke would be at dinner:

lines.speaker: Ra.
lines.text: Make a short Shrift, he longs to see your Head.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: O momentarie grace of mortall men,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Which we more hunt for, then the grace of God!

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Who builds his hope in ayre of your good Lookes,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Liues like a drunken Sayler on a Mast,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Readie with euery Nod to tumble downe,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Into the fatall Bowels of the Deepe.

lines.speaker: Lou.
lines.text: Come, come, dispatch, 'tis bootlesse to exclaime.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: O bloody {% italic: Richard: %} miserable England,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: I prophecie the fearefull'st time to thee,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: That euer wretched Age hath look'd vpon.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Come, lead me to the Block, beare him my Head,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: They smile at me, who shortly shall be dead.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Come Cousin,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Canst thou quake, and change thy colour,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Murther thy breath in middle of a word,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: And then againe begin, and stop againe,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: As if thou were distraught, and mad with terror ?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Tut, I can counterfeit the deepe Tragedian,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Speake, and looke backe, and prie on euery side,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Tremble and start at wagging of a Straw:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Intending deepe suspition, gastly Lookes

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Are at my seruice, like enforced Smiles;

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And both are readie in their Offices,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: At any time to grace my Stratagemes.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But what, is {% italic: Catesby %} gone?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: He is, and see he brings the Maior along.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Lord Maior.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Looke to the Draw‑Bridge there.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Hearke, a Drumme.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Catesby %}, o're‑looke the Walls.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Lord Maior, the reason we haue sent.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Looke back, defend thee, here are Enemies.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: God and our Innocencie defend, and guard vs.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Be patient, they are friends: {% italic: Ratcliffe %}, and {% italic: Louell %}.

lines.speaker: Louell.
lines.text: Here is the Head of that ignoble Traytor,

lines.speaker: Louell.
lines.text: The dangerous and vnsuspected {% italic: Hastings %}.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So deare I lou'd the man, that I must weepe:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I tooke him for the plainest harmelesse Creature,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That breath'd vpon the Earth, a Christian.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Made him my Booke, wherein my Soule recorded

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Historie of all her secret thoughts.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So smooth he dawb'd his Vice with shew of Vertue,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That his apparant open Guilt omitted,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I meane, his Conuersation with {% italic: Shores %} Wife,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: He liu'd from all attainder of suspects.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Well, well, he was the couertst sheltred Traytor

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: That euer liu'd.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Would you imagine, or almost beleeue,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Wert not, that by great preseruation

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: We liue to tell it, that the subtill Traytor

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: This day had plotted, in the Councell‑House,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To murther me, and my good Lord of Gloster.

lines.speaker: Maior.
lines.text: Had he done so?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What? thinke you we are Turkes, or Infidels?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Or that we would, against the forme of Law,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Proceed thus rashly in the Villaines death,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But that the extreme perill of the case,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Peace of England, and our Persons safetie,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Enforc'd vs to this Execution.

lines.speaker: Maior.
lines.text: Now faire befall you, he deseru'd his death,

lines.speaker: Maior.
lines.text: And your good Graces both haue well proceeded,

lines.speaker: Maior.
lines.text: To warne false Traytors from the like Attempts.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: I neuer look'd for better at his hands,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: After he once fell in with Mistresse {% italic: Shore: %}

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Yet had we not determin'd he should dye,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Vntiil your Lordship came to see his end,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Which now the louing haste of these our friends,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Something against our meanings, haue preuented;

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Because, my Lord, I would haue had you heard

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: The Traytor speake, and timorously confesse

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: The manner and the purpose of his Treasons:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: That you might well haue signify'd the same

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Vnto the Citizens, who haply may

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Misconster vs in him, and wayle his death.

lines.speaker: Ma.
lines.text: But, my good Lord, your Graces words shal serue,

lines.speaker: Ma.
lines.text: As well as I had seene, and heard him speake:

lines.speaker: Ma.
lines.text: And doe not doubt, right Noble Princes both,

lines.speaker: Ma.
lines.text: But Ile acquaint our dutious Citizens

lines.speaker: Ma.
lines.text: With all your iust proceedings in this case.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And to that end we wish'd your Lordship here,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: T'auoid the Censures of the carping World.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Which since you come too late of our intent,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Yet witnesse what you heare we did intend:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And so, my good Lord Maior, we bid farwell.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Goe after, after, Cousin {% italic: Buckingham %}.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Maior towards Guild‑Hall hyes him in all poste:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: There, at your meetest vantage of the time,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Inferre the Bastardie of {% italic: Edwards %} Children:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Tell them, how {% italic: Edward %} put to death a Citizen,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Onely for saying, he would make his Sonne

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Heire to the Crowne, meaning indeed his House,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which, by the Signe thereof, was tearmed so.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Moreouer, vrge his hatefull Luxurie,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And beastiall appetite in change of Lust,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which stretcht vnto their Seruants, Daughters, Wiues,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Euen where his raging eye, or sauage heart,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Without controll, lusted to make a prey.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Nay, for a need, thus farre come neere my Person:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Tell them, when that my Mother went with Child

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of that insatiate {% italic: Edward %}; Noble {% italic: Yorke %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Princely Father, then had Warres in France,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And by true computation of the time,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Found, that the Issue was not his begot:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which well appeared in his Lineaments,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Being nothing like the Noble Duke, my Father:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Yet touch this sparingly, as 'twere farre off,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Because, my Lord, you know my Mother liues.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Doubt not, my Lord, Ile play the Orator,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: As if the Golden Fee, for which I plead,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Were for my selfe: and so, my Lord, adue.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If you thriue wel, bring them to Baynards Castle,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Where you shall finde me well accompanied

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With reuerend Fathers, and well‑learned Bishops.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: I goe, and towards three or foure a Clocke

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Looke for the Newes that the Guild‑Hall affoords.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Goe {% italic: Louell %} with all speed to Doctor {% italic: Shaw %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Goe thou to Fryer {% italic: Peuker %}, bid them both

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Meet me within this houre at Baynards Castle.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now will I goe to take some priuie order,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To draw the Brats of {% italic: Clarence %} out of sight,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And to giue order, that no manner person

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Haue any time recourse vnto the Princes.

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: Here is the Indictment of the good Lord {% italic: Hastings %},

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: Which in a set Hand fairely is engross'd,

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: That it may be to day read o're in {% italic: Paules %}.

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: And marke how well the sequell hangs together:

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: Eleuen houres I haue spent to write it ouer,

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: For yester‑night by {% italic: Catesby %} was it sent me,

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: The Precedent was full as long a doing,

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: And yet within these fiue houres {% italic: Hastings %} liu'd,

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: Vntainted, vnexamin'd, free, at libertie.

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: Here's a good World the while.

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: Who is so grosse, that cannot see this palpable deuice?

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: Yet who so bold, but sayes he sees it not?

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: Bad is the World, and all will come to nought,

lines.speaker: Scr.
lines.text: When such ill dealing must be seene in thought.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: How now, how now, what say the Citizens?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Now by the holy Mother of our Lord,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: The Citizens are mum, say not a word.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Toucht you the Bastardie of {% italic: Edwards %} Children?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: I did, with his Contract with Lady {% italic: Lucy %},

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And his Contract by Deputie in France,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Th'vnsatiate greedinesse of his desire,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And his enforcement of the Citie Wiues,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: His Tyrannie for Trifles, his owne Bastardie,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: As being got, your Father then in France,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And his resemblance, being not like the Duke.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Withall, I did inferre your Lineaments,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Being the right {% italic: Idea %} of your Father,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Both in your forme, and Noblenesse of Minde:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Layd open all your Victories in Scotland,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Your Discipline in Warre, Wisdome in Peace,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Your Bountie, Vertue, faire Humilitie:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Indeed, left nothing fitting for your purpose,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Vntoucht, or sleightly handled in discourse.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And when my Oratorie drew toward end,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: I bid them that did loue their Countries good,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Cry, God saue {% italic: Richard %}, Englands Royall King.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And did they so?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: No, so God helpe me, they spake not a word,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But like dumbe Statues, or breathing Stones,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Star'd each on other, and look'd deadly pale:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Which when I saw, I reprehended them,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And ask'd the Maior, what meant this wilfull silence?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: His answer was, the people were not vsed

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To be spoke to, but by the Recorder.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Then he was vrg'd to tell my Tale againe:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Thus sayth the Duke, thus hath the Duke inferr'd,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But nothing spoke, in warrant from himselfe.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: When he had done, some followers of mine owne,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: At lower end of the Hall, hurld vp their Caps,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And some tenne voyces cry'd, God saue King {% italic: Richard: %}

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And thus I tooke the vantage of those few.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Thankes gentle Citizens, and friends, quoth I,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: This generall applause, and chearefull showt,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Argues your wisdome, and your loue to {% italic: Richard: %}

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And euen here brake off, and came away.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What tongue‑lesse Blockes were they,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Would they not speake?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Will not the Maior then, and his Brethren, come?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: The Maior is here at hand: intend some feare,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Be not you spoke with, but by mightie suit:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And looke you get a Prayer‑Booke in your hand,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And stand betweene two Church‑men, good my Lord,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: For on that ground Ile make a holy Descant:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And be not easily wonne to our requests,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Play the Maids part, still answer nay, and take it.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I goe: and if you plead as well for them,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As I can say nay to thee for my selfe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: No doubt we bring it to a happie issue.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Go, go vp to the Leads, the Lord Maior knocks.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Welcome, my Lord, I dance attendance here,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: I thinke the Duke will not be spoke withall.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Now {% italic: Catesby %}, what sayes your Lord to my ?

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: He doth entreat your Grace, my Noble Lord,

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: To visit him to morrow, or next day:

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: He is within, with two right reuerend Fathers,

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: Diuinely bent to Meditation,

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: And in no Worldly suites would he be mou'd,

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: To draw him from his holy Exercise.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Returne, good {% italic: Catesby %}, to the gracious Duke,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Tell him, my selfe, the Maior and Aldermen,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: In deepe designes, in matter of great moment,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: No lesse importing then our generall good,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Are come to haue some conference with his Grace.

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: Ile signifie so much vnto him straight.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Ah ha, my Lord, this Prince is not an {% italic: Edward %},

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: He is not lulling on a lewd Loue‑Bed,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But on his Knees, at Meditation:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Not dallying with a Brace of Curtizans,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But meditating with two deepe Diuines:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Not sleeping, to engrosse his idle Body,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But praying, to enrich his watchfull Soule.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Happie were England, would this vertuous Prince

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Take on his Grace the Soueraigntie thereof.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But sure I feare we shall not winne him to it.

lines.speaker: Maior.
lines.text: Marry God defend his Grace should say vs

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: I feare he will: here {% italic: Catesby %} comes againe.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Now {% italic: Catesby %}, what sayes his Grace?

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: He wonders to what end you haue assembled

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: Such troopes of Citizens, to come to him,

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: His Grace not being warn'd thereof before:

lines.speaker: Catesby.
lines.text: He feares, my Lord, you meane no good to him.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Sorry I am, my Noble Cousin should

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Suspect me, that I meane no good to him:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: By Heauen, we come to him in perfit loue,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And so once more returne, and tell his Grace.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: When holy and deuout Religious men

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Are at their Beades, 'tis much to draw them thence,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: So sweet is zealous Contemplation.

lines.speaker: Maior.
lines.text: See where his Grace stands, tweene two Clergie

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Two Props of Vertue, for a Christian Prince,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To stay him from the fall of Vanitie:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And see a Booke of Prayer in his hand,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: True Ornaments to know a holy man.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Famous {% italic: Plantagenet %}, most gracious Prince,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Lend fauourable eare to our requests,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And pardon vs the interruption

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Of thy Deuotion, and right Christian Zeale.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Lord, there needs no such Apologie:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I doe beseech your Grace to pardon me,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Who earnest in the seruice of my God,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Deferr'd the visitation of my friends.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But leauing this, what is your Graces pleasure?

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Euen that (I hope {% italic: ) %} which pleaseth God aboue,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And all good men, of this vngouern'd Ile.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I doe suspect I haue done some offence,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That seemes disgracious in the Cities eye,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: You haue, my Lord:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Would it might please your Grace,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: On our entreaties, to amend your fault.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian Land.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Know then, it is your fault, that you resigne

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: The Supreme Seat, the Throne Maiesticall,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: The Sceptred Office of your Ancestors,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Your State of Fortune, and your Deaw of Birth,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: The Lineall Glory of your Royall House,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To the corruption of a blemisht Stock;

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Whiles in the mildnesse of your sleepie thoughts,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Which here we waken to our Countries good,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: The Noble Ile doth want his proper Limmes:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: His Face defac'd with skarres of Infamie,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: His Royall Stock grafft with ignoble Plants,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And almost shouldred in the swallowing Gulfe

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Of darke Forgetfulnesse, and deepe Obliuion.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Which to recure, we heartily solicite

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Your gracious selfe to take on you the charge

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And Kingly Gouernment of this your Land:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Not as Protector, Steward, Substitute,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Or lowly Factor, for anothers gaine;

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But as suceessiuely, from Blood to Blood,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Your Right of Birth, your Empyrie, your owne.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: For this, consorted with the Citizens,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Your very Worshipfull and louing friends,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And by their vehement instigation,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: In this iust Cause come I to moue your Grace.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I cannot tell, if to depart in silence,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Or bitterly to speake in your reproofe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Best fitteth my Degree, or your Condition.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If not to answer, you might haply thinke,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Tongue‑ty'd Ambition, not replying, yeelded

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To beare the Golden Yoake of Soueraigntie,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which fondly you would here impose on me.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If to reproue you for this suit of yours,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So season'd with your faithfull loue to me,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then on the other side I check'd my friends.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Therefore to speake, and to auoid the first,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And then in speaking, not to incurre the last,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Definitiuely thus I answer you.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your loue deserues my thankes, but my desert

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vnmeritable, shunnes your high request.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: First, if all Obstacles were cut away,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And that my Path were euen to the Crowne,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As the ripe Reuenue, and due of Birth:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Yet so much is my pouertie of spirit,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So mightie, and so manie my defects,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That I would rather hide me from my Greatnesse,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Being a Barke to brooke no mightie Sea;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then in my Greatnesse couet to be hid,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And in the vapour of my Glory smother'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But God be thank'd, there is no need of me,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And much I need to helpe you, were there need:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Royall Tree hath left vs Royall Fruit,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which mellow'd by the stealing howres of time,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Will well become the Seat of Maiestie,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And make (no doubt) vs happy by his Reigne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: On him I lay that, you would lay on me,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Right and Fortune of his happie Starres,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which God defend that I should wring from him.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: My Lord, this argues Conscience in your Grace,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But the respects thereof are nice, and triuiall,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: All circumstances well considered.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: You say, that {% italic: Edward %} is your Brothers Sonne,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: So say we too, but not by {% italic: Edwards %} Wife:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: For first was he contract to Lady {% italic: Lucie %},

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Your Mother liues a Witnesse to his Vow;

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And afterward by substitute betroth'd

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To {% italic: Bona %}, Sister to the King of France.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: These both put off, a poore Petitioner,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: A Care‑cras'd Mother to a many Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: A Beautie‑waining, and distressed Widow,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Euen in the after‑noone of her best dayes,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Made prize and purchase of his wanton Eye,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Seduc'd the pitch, and height of his degree,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To base declension, and loath'd Bigamie.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: By her, in his vnlawfull Bed, he got

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: This {% italic: Edward %}, whom our Manners call the Prince.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: More bitterly could I expostulate,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Saue that for reuerence to some aliue,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: I giue a sparing limit to my Tongue.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Then good, my Lord, take to your Royall selfe

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: This proffer'd benefit of Dignitie:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: If not to blesse vs and the Land withall,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Yet to draw forth your Noble Ancestrie

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: From the corruption of abusing times,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Vnto a Lineall true deriued course.

lines.speaker: Maior.
lines.text: Do good my Lord, your Citizens entreat you.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Refuse not, mightie Lord, this proffer'd loue.

lines.speaker: Catesb.
lines.text: O make them ioyfull, grant their lawfull suit.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Alas, why would you heape this Care on me?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I am vnfit for State, and Maiestie:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I doe beseech you take it not amisse,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I cannot, nor I will not yeeld to you.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: If you refuse it, as in loue and zeale,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Loth to depose the Child, your Brothers Sonne,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: As well we know your tendernesse of heart,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And gentle, kinde, effeminate remorse,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Which we haue noted in you to your Kindred,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And egally indeede to all Estates:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Yet know, where you accept our suit, or no,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Your Brothers Sonne shall neuer reigne our King,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: But we will plant some other in the Throne,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To the disgrace and downe‑fall of your House:

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And in this resolution here we leaue you.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Come Citizens, we will entreat no more.

lines.speaker: Catesb.
lines.text: Call him againe, sweet Prince, accept their suit:

lines.speaker: Catesb.
lines.text: If you denie them, all the Land will rue it.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Will you enforce me to a world of Cares.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Call them againe, I am not made of Stones,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But penetrable to your kinde entreaties,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Albeit against my Conscience and my Soule.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Cousin of Buckingham, and sage graue men,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Since you will buckle fortune on my back,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To beare her burthen, where I will or no.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I must haue patience to endure the Load:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But if black Scandall, or foule‑fac'd Reproach,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Attend the sequell of your Imposition,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your meere enforcement shall acquittance me

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: From all the impure blots and staynes thereof;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For God doth know, and you may partly see,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: How farre I am from the desire of this.

lines.speaker: Maior.
lines.text: God blesse your Grace, wee see it, and will

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Then I salute you with this Royall Title,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: Long liue King {% italic: Richard %}, Englands worthie King.

lines.speaker: All.
lines.text: Amen.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To morrow may it please you to be Crown'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Euen when you please, for you will haue it so.

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: To morrow then we will attend your Grace,

lines.speaker: Buck.
lines.text: And so most ioyfully we take our leaue.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Come, let vs to our holy Worke againe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Farewell my Cousins, farewell gentle friends.

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: Who meetes vs heere?

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: My Neece {% italic: Plantagenet %},

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: Led in the hand of her kind Aunt of Gloster?

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: Now, for my Life, shee's wandring to the Tower,

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: On pure hearts loue, to greet the tender Prince.

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: Daughter, well met.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: God giue your Graces both, a happie

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: And a ioyfull time of day.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: As much to you, good Sister: whither away?

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: No farther then the Tower, and as I guesse,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Vpon the like deuotion as your selues,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: To gratulate the gentle Princes there.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Kind Sister thankes, wee'le enter all together:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And in good time, here the Lieutenant comes.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Master Lieutenant, pray you, by your leaue,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: How doth the Prince, and my young Sonne of {% italic: Yorke %}?

lines.speaker: Lieu.
lines.text: Right well, deare Madame: by your patience,

lines.speaker: Lieu.
lines.text: I may not suffer you to visit them,

lines.speaker: Lieu.
lines.text: The King hath strictly charg'd the contrary.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The King? who's that?

lines.speaker: Lieu.
lines.text: I meane, the Lord Protector.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The Lord protect him from that Kingly Title.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Hath he set bounds betweene their loue, and me?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I am their Mother, who shall barre me from them?

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: I am their Fathers Mother, I will see

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Their Aunt I am in law, in loue their Mother:

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Then bring me to their sights, Ile beare thy blame,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: And take thy Office from thee, on my perill.

lines.speaker: Lieu.
lines.text: No, Madame, no; I may not leaue it so:

lines.speaker: Lieu.
lines.text: I am bound by Oath, and therefore pardon me.

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: Let me but meet you Ladies one howre hence,

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: And Ile salute your Grace of Yorke as Mother,

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: And reuerend looker on of two faire Queenes,

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: Come Madame, you must straight to Westminster,

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: There to be crowned {% italic: Richards %} Royall Queene.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Ah, cut my Lace asunder,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That my pent heart may haue some scope to beat,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Or else I swoone with this dead‑killing newes.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Despightfull tidings, O vnpleasing newes.

lines.speaker: Dors.
lines.text: Be of good cheare: Mother, how fares your

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: O {% italic: Dorset %}, speake not to me, get thee gone,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Death and Destruction dogges thee at thy heeles,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thy Mothers Name is ominous to Children.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: If thou wilt out‑strip Death, goe crosse the Seas,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And liue with {% italic: Richmond %}, from the reach of Hell.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Goe hye thee, hye thee from this slaughter‑house,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Lest thou encrease the number of the dead,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And make me dye the thrall of {% italic: Margarets %} Curse,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Nor Mother, Wife, nor Englands counted Queene.

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: Full of wise care, is this your counsaile, Madame:

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: Take all the swift aduantage of the howres:

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: You shall haue Letters from me to my Sonne,

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: In your behalfe, to meet you on the way:

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: Be not ta'ne tardie by vnwise delay.

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: O ill dispersing Winde of Miserie,

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: O my accursed Wombe, the Bed of Death:

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: A Cockatrice hast thou hatcht to the World,

lines.speaker: Duch. Yorke.
lines.text: Whose vnauoided Eye is murtherous.

lines.speaker: Stanley.
lines.text: Come, Madame, come, I in all haste was sent.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: And I with all vnwillingnesse will goe.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: O would to God, that the inclusiue Verge

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Of Golden Mettall, that must round my Brow,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Were red hot Steele, to seare me to the Braines,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Anoynted let me be with deadly Venome,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: And dye ere men can say, God saue the Queene.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Goe, goe, poore soule, I enuie not thy glory,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To feed my humor, with thy selfe no harme.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: No: why ? When he that is my Husband now,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Came to me, as I follow'd {% italic: Henries %} Corse,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: When scarce the blood was well washt from his hands,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Which issued from my other Angell Husband,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: And that deare Saint, which then I weeping follow'd:

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: O, when I say I look'd on {% italic: Richards %} Face,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: This was my Wish: Be thou (quoth I) accurst,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: For making me, so young, so old a Widow:

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: And when thou wed'st, let sorrow haunt thy Bed;

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: And be thy Wife, if any be so mad,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: More miserable, by the Life of thee,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Then thou hast made me, by my deare Lords death.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Loe, ere I can repeat this Curse againe,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Within so small a time, my Womans heart

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Grossely grew captiue to his honey words,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: And prou'd the subiect of mine owne Soules Curse,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Which hitherto hath held mine eyes from rest:

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: For neuer yet one howre in his Bed

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Did I enioy the golden deaw of sleepe,

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: But with his timorous Dreames was still awak'd.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Besides, he hates me for my Father {% italic: Warwicke %},

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: And will (no doubt) shortly be rid of me.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Poore heart adieu, I pittie thy complaining.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: No more, then with my soule I mourne for

lines.speaker: Dors.
lines.text: Farewell, thou wofull welcommer of glory.

lines.speaker: Anne.
lines.text: Adieu, poore soule, that tak'st thy leaue

lines.speaker: Du. Y.
lines.text: Go thou to {% italic: Richmond %}, & good fortune guide thee,

lines.speaker: Du. Y.
lines.text: Go thou to {% italic: Richard %}, and good Angels tend thee,

lines.speaker: Du. Y.
lines.text: Go thou to Sanctuarie, and good thoughts possesse thee,

lines.speaker: Du. Y.

lines.speaker: Mar.
