lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And leaue the burthen of it all, on thee.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Farwell Yorkes wife, and Queene of sad mischance,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: These English woes, shall make me smile in France.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: O thou well skill'd in Curses, stay a‑while,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And teach me how to curse mine enemies.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Forbeare to sleepe the night, and fast the day:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Compare dead happinesse, with liuing woe:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Thinke that thy Babes were sweeter then they were,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And he that slew them fowler then he is:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Bett'ring thy losse, makes the bad causer worse,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Reuoluing this, will teach thee how to Curse.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: My words are dull, O quicken them with thine.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Thy woes will make them sharpe,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And pierce like mine.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Why should calamity be full of words?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Windy Atturnies to their Clients Woes,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Ayery succeeders of intestine ioyes,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Poore breathing Orators of miseries,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Let them haue scope, though what they will impart,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Helpe nothing els, yet do they ease the hart.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: If so then, be not Tongue‑ty'd: go with me,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And in the breath of bitter words, let's smother

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: My damned Son, that thy two sweet Sonnes smother'd.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: The Trumpet sounds, be copious in exclaimes.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Who intercepts me in my Expedition?

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: O she, that might haue intercepted thee

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: By strangling thee in her accursed wombe,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: From all the slaughters (Wretch) that thou hast done.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Hid'st thou that Forhead with a Golden Crowne

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Where't should be branded, if that right were right?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The slaughter of the Prince that ow'd that Crowne,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And the dyre death of my poore Sonnes, and Brothers.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Tell me thou Villaine‑slaue, where are my Children?

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Thou Toad, thou Toade,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Where is thy Brother {% italic: Clarence %}?

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And little {% italic: Ned Plantagenet %} his Sonne?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Where is the gentle {% italic: Riuers, Vaughan, Gray %}?

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Where is kinde {% italic: Hastings %}?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A flourish Trumpets, strike Alarum Drummes:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Let not the Heauens heare these Tell‑tale women

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Raile on the Lords Annointed. Strike I say.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Either be patient, and intreat me fayre,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Or with the clamorous report of Warre,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thus will I drowne your exclamations.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Art thou my Sonne?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, I thanke God, my Father, and your selfe.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Then patiently heare my impatience.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Madam, I haue a touch of your condition,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That cannot brooke the accent of reproofe.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: O let me speake.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Do then, but Ile not heare.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: I will be milde, and gentle in my words.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And breefe (good Mother) for I am in hast.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Art thou so hasty? I haue staid for thee

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: (God knowes) in torment and in agony.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And came I not at last to comfort you?

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: No by the holy Rood, thou know'st it well,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Thou cam'st on earth, to make the earth my Hell.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: A greeuous burthen was thy Birth to me,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Tetchy and wayward was thy Infancie.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Thy School‑daies frightfull, desp'rate, wilde, and furious,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Thy prime of Manhood, daring, bold, and venturous:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Thy Age confirm'd, proud, subtle, slye, and bloody,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: More milde, but yet more harmfull; Kinde in hatred:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: What comfortable houre canst thou name,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: That euer grac'd me with thy company?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Faith none, but {% italic: Humfrey Hower %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That call'd your Grace

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To Breakefast once, forth of my company.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If I be so disgracious in your eye,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Let me march on, and not offend you Madam.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Strike vp the Drumme.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: I prythee heare me speake.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: You speake too bitterly.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Heare me a word:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: For I shall neuer speake to thee againe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Either thou wilt dye, by Gods iust ordinance

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Ere from this warre thou turne a Conqueror:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Or I with greefe and extreame Age shall perish,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And neuer more behold thy face againe.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Therefore take with thee my most greeuous Curse,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Which in the day of Battell tyre thee more

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Then all the compleat Armour that thou wear'st.

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: My Prayers on the aduerse party fight,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And there the little soules of {% italic: Edwards %} Children,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Whisper the Spirits of thine Enemies,

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: And promise them Successe and Victory:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end:

lines.speaker: Dut.
lines.text: Shame serues thy life, and doth thy death attend.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Though far more cause, yet much lesse spirit to curse

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Abides in me, I say Amen to her.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Stay Madam, I must talke a word with you.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I haue no more sonnes of the Royall Blood

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: For thee to slaughter. For my Daughters ( {% italic: Richard %})

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: They shall be praying Nunnes, not weeping Queenes:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And therefore leuell not to hit their liues.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: You haue a daughter call'd {% italic: Elizabeth %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vertuous and Faire, Royall and Gracious?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And must she dye for this? O let her liue,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And Ile corrupt her Manners, staine her Beauty,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Slander my Selfe, as false to {% italic: Edwards %} bed:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Throw ouer her the vaile of Infamy,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: So she may liue vnscarr'd of bleeding slaughter,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I will confesse she was not {% italic: Edwards %} daughter.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Wrong not her Byrth, she is a Royall Princesse.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To saue her life, Ile say she is not so.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Her life is safest onely in her byrth.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And onely in that safety, dyed her Brothers.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Loe at their Birth, good starres were opposite.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: No, to their liues, ill friends were contrary.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: All vnauoyded is the doome of Destiny.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: True: when auoyded grace makes Destiny.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: My Babes were destin'd to a fairer death,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: If grace had blest thee with a fairer life.

lines.speaker: Rich,
lines.text: You speake as if that I had slaine my Cosins?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Cosins indeed, and by their Vnckle couzend,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Of Comfort, Kingdome, Kindred, Freedome, Life,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Whose hand soeuer lanch'd their tender hearts,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thy head (all indirectly) gaue direction.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: No doubt the murd'rous Knife was dull and blunt,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Till it was whetted on thy stone‑hard heart,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To reuell in the Intrailes of my Lambes.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But that still vse of greefe, makes wilde greefe tame,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: My tongue should to thy eares not name my Boyes,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Till that my Nayles were anchor'd in thine eyes:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And I in such a desp'rate Bay of death,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Like a poore Barke, of sailes and tackling reft,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Rush all to peeces on thy Rocky bosome.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Madam, so thriue I in my enterprize

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And dangerous successe of bloody warres,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As I intend more good to you and yours,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then euer you and yours by me were harm'd.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What good is couer'd with the face of heauen,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To be discouered, that can do me good.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Th'aduancement of your children, gentle Lady

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Vp to some Scaffold, there to lose their heads.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vnto the dignity and height of Fortune,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The high Imperiall Type of this earths glory.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Flatter my sorrow with report of it:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Tell me, what State, what Dignity, what Honor,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Canst thou demise to any childe of mine.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Euen all I haue; I, and my selfe and all,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Will I withall indow a childe of thine:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So in the Lethe of thy angry soule,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thou drowne the sad remembrance of those wrongs,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which thou supposest I haue done to thee.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Be breefe, least that the processe of thy kindnesse

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Last longer telling then thy kindness date.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then know,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That from my Soule, I loue thy Daughter.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: My daughters Mother thinkes it with her soule.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What do you thinke?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That thou dost loue my daughter from thy soule

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: So from thy Soules loue didst thou loue her Brothers,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And from my hearts loue, I do thanke thee for it.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I meane that with my Soule I loue thy daughter,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And do intend to make her Queene of England.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Well then, who dost y u meane shallbe her King.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Euen he that makes her Queene:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Who else should bee?

lines.speaker: Q
lines.text: What, thou?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Euen so: How thinke you of it?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: How canst thou woo her?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That I would learne of you,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As one being best acquainted with her humour.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And wilt thou learne of me ?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Madam, with all my heart.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Send to her by the man that slew her Brothers,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: A paire of bleeding hearts: thereon ingraue

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: {% italic: Edward %} and {% italic: Yorke %}, then haply will she weepe:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Therefore present to her, as sometime {% italic: Margaret %}

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Did to thy Father, steept in Rutlands blood,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: A hand‑kercheefe, which say to her did dreyne

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The purple sappe from her sweet Brothers body,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And bid her wipe her weeping eyes withall.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: If this inducement moue her not to loue,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Send her a Letter of thy Noble deeds:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Tell her, thou mad'st away her Vnckle {% italic: Clarence %},

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Her Vnckle {% italic: Riuers %}, I (and for her sake)

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Mad'st quicke conueyance with her good Aunt {% italic: Anne %}.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: You mocke me Madam, this not the way

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To win your daughter.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: There is no other way,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Vnlesse thou could'st put on some other shape,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And not be {% italic: Richard %}, that hath done all this.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Say that 1 did all this for loue of her.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Nay then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Hauing bought loue, with such a bloody spoyle.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Looke what is done, cannot be now amended:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Men shall deale vnaduisedly sometimes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which after‑houres giues leysure to repent.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If I did take the Kingdome from your Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To make amends, Ile giue it to your daughter:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If I haue kill'd the issue of your wombe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To quicken your encrease, I will beget

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Mine yssue of your blood, vpon your Daughter:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A Grandams name is little lesse in loue,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then is the doting Title of a Mother;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: They are as Children but one steppe below,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Euen of your mettall, of your very blood:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of all one paine, saue for a night of groanes

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Endur'd of her, for whom you bid like sorrow.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your Children were vexation to your youth,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But mine shall be a comfort to your Age,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The losse you haue, is but a Sonne being King,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And by that losse, your Daughter is made Queene.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I cannot make you what amends I would,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Therefore accept such kindnesse as I can.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Dorset %} your Sonne, that with a fearfull soule

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Leads discontented steppes in Forraine soyle,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: This faire Alliance, quickly shall call home

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To high Promotions, and great Dignity.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The King that calles your beauteous Daughter Wife,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Familiarly shall call thy {% italic: Dorset %}, Brother:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Againe shall you be Mother to a King:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And all the Ruines of distressefull Times,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Repayr'd with double Riches of Content.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What? we haue many goodly dayes to see:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The liquid drops of Teares that you haue shed,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shall come againe, transform'd to Orient Pearle,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Aduantaging their Loue, with interest

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of ten‑times double gaine of happinesse.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Go then (my Mother) to thy Daughter go,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Make bold her bashfull yeares, with your experience,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Prepare her eares to heare a Woers Tale.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Put in her tender heart, th'aspiring Flame

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of Golden Soueraignty: Acquaint the Princesse

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With the sweet silent houres of Marriage ioyes:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And when this Arme of mine hath chastised

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The petty Rebell, dull‑brain'd {% italic: Buckingham %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Bound with Triumphant Garlands will I come,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And leade thy daughter to a Conquerors bed:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To whom I will retaile my Conquest wonne,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And she shalbe sole Victoresse, {% italic: Cæsars Cæsar %}.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What were I best to say, her Fathers Brother

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Would be her Lord ? Or shall I say her Vnkle?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Or he that slew her Brothers, and her Vnkles?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Vnder what Title shall I woo for thee,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That God, the Law, my Honor, and her Loue,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Can make seeme pleasing to her tender yeares?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Inferre faire Englands peace by this Alliance.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Which she shall purchase with stil lasting warre.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Tell her, the King that may command, intreats.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That at her hands, which the kings King forbids.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Say she shall be a High and Mighty Queene.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To vaile the Title, as her Mother doth.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Say I will loue her euerlastingly.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But how long shall that title euer last?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Sweetly in force, vnto her faire liues end.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But how long fairely shall her sweet life last?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As long as Heauen and Nature lengthens it.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: As long as Hell and {% italic: Richard %} likes of it.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Say, I her Soueraigne, am her Subiect low.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But she your Subiect, lothes such Soueraignty.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Be eloquent in my behalfe to her.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: An honest tale speeds best, being plainly told.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then plainly, to her, tell my louing tale.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Plaine and not honest, is too harsh a style.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your Reasons are too shallow, and to quicke.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: O no, my Reasons are too deepe and dead,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Too deepe and dead (poore Infants) in their graues,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Harpe on it still shall I, till heart‑strings breake.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Harpe not on that string Madam, that is past.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now by my George, my Garter, and my Crowne.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Prophan'd, dishonor'd, and the third vsurpt.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I sweare.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: By nothing, for this is no Oath:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thy George prophan'd, hath lost his Lordly Honor;

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thy Garter blemish'd, pawn'd his Knightly Vertue;

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thy Crowne vsurp'd, disgrac'd his Kingly Glory:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: If something thou would'st sweare to be beleeu'd,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Sweare then by something, that thou hast not wrong'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then by my Selfe.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thy Selfe, is selfe‑misvs'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now by the World.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: 'Tis full of thy foule wrongs.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Fathers death.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thy life hath it dishonor'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Why then, by Heauen.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Hea uens wrong is most of all:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: If thou didd'st feare to breake an Oath with him,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The vnity the King my husband made,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thou had'st not broken, nor my Brothers died.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: If thou had'st fear'd to breake an oath by him,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Th'Imperiall mettall, circling now thy head,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Had grac'd the tender temples of my Child,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And both the Princes had bene breathing heere,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Which now two tender Bed‑fellowes for dust,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thy broken Faith hath made the prey for Wormes.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What can'st thou sweare by now.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The time to come.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That thou hast wronged in the time ore‑past:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: For I my selfe haue many teares to wash

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Heereafter time, for time past, wrong'd by thee.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The Children liue, whose Fathers thou hast slaughter'd,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Vngouern'd youth, to waile it with their age:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The Parents liue, whose Children thou hast butcher'd,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Old barren Plants, to waile it with their Age.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Sweare not by time to come, for that thou hast

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Misvs'd ere vs'd, by times ill‑vs'd repast.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As I entend to prosper, and repent:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So thriue I in my dangerous Affayres

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of hostile Armes: My selfe, my selfe confound:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Heauen, and Fortune barre me happy houres:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Day, yeeld me not thy light; nor Night, thy rest.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Be opposite all Planets of good lucke

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To my proceeding, if with deere hearts loue,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Immaculate deuotion, holy thoughts,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I tender not thy beautious Princely daughter.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: In her, consists my Happinesse, and thine:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Without her, followes to my selfe, and thee;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Her selfe, the Land, and many a Christian soule,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Death, Desolation, Ruine, and Decay:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: It cannot be auoyded, but by this:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: It will not be auoyded, but by this.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Therefore deare Mother (I must call you so)

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Be the Atturney of my loue to her:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Pleade what I will be, not what I haue beene;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Not my deserts, but what I will deserue:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vrge the Necessity and state of times,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And be not peeuish found, in great Designes.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Shall I be tempted of the Diuel thus?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, if the Diuell tempt you to do good.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Shall I forget my selfe, to be my selfe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, if your selfes remembrance wrong your selfe.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Yet thou didst kil my Children.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But in your daughters wombe I bury them.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Where in that Nest of Spicery they will breed

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Selues of themselues, to your recomforture.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will ?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And be a happy Mother by the deed.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I go, write to me very shortly,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And you shal vnderstand from me her mind.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Beare her my true loues kisse, and so farewell.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Relenting Foole, and shallow‑changing Woman.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: How now, what newes?

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: Most mightie Soueraigne, on the Westerne Coast

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: Rideth a puissant Nauie: to our Shores

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: Throng many doubtfull hollow‑hearted friends,

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: Vnarm'd, and vnresolu'd to beat them backe.

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: 'Tis thought, that {% italic: Richmond %} is their Admirall:

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: And there they hull, expecting but the aide

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: Of {% italic: Buckingham %}, to welcome them ashore.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Some light‑foot friend post to yͤ Duke of Norfolk:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Ratcliffe %} thy selfe, or {% italic: Catesby %}, where is hee?

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: Here, my good Lord.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Catesby %}, flye to the Duke.

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: I will, my Lord, with all conuenient haste.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Catesby %} come hither, poste to Salisbury:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: When thou com'st thither: Dull vnmindfull Villaine,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Why stay'st thou here, and go'st not to the Duke?

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: First, mighty Liege, tell me your Highnesse pleasure,

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: What from your Grace I shall deliuer to him.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: O true, good {% italic: Catesby %}, bid him leuie straight

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The greatest strength and power that he can make,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And meet me suddenly at Salisbury.

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: I goe.

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: What, may it please you, shall I doe at Salis­

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Why, what would'st thou doe there, before I

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: Your Highnesse told me I should poste before.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My minde is chang'd:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Stanley %}, what newes with you?

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: None, good my Liege, to please you with yͤ hearing,

lines.speaker: Sta.
lines.text: Nor none so bad, but well may be reported.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Hoyday, a Riddle, neither good nor bad:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What need'st thou runne so many miles about,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: When thou mayest tell thy Tale the neerest way?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Once more, what newes?

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: {% italic: Richmond %} is on the Seas.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: There let him sinke, and be the Seas on him,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: White‑liuer'd Runnagate, what doth he there?

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: I know not, mightie Soueraigne, but by guesse.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Well, as you guesse.

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: Stirr'd vp by {% italic: Dorset, Buckingham %}, and {% italic: Morton %},

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: He makes for England, here to clayme the Crowne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is the Chayre emptie? is the Sword vnsway'd?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is the King dead? the Empire vnpossest?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What Heire of {% italic: Yorke %} is there aliue, but wee?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And who is Englands King, but great {% italic: Yorkes %} Heire?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then tell me, what makes he vpon the Seas?

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: Vnlesse for that, my Liege, I cannot guesse.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vnlesse for that he comes to be your Liege,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: You cannot guesse wherefore the Welchman comes.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thou wilt reuolt, and flye to him, I feare.

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: No, my good Lord, therefore mistrust me not.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Where is thy Power then, to beat him back ?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Where be thy Tenants, and thy followers?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Are they not now vpon the Westerne Shore,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Safe‑conducting the Rebels from their Shippes?

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: No, my good Lord, my friends are in the

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Cold friends to me: what do they in the North,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: When they should serue their Soueraigne in the West?

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: They haue not been commanded, mighty King:

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: Pleaseth your Maiestie to giue me leaue,

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: Ile muster vp my friends, and meet your Grace,

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: Where, and what time your Maiestie shall please.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, thou would'st be gone, to ioyne with {% italic: Richmond: %}

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But Ile not trust thee.

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: Most mightie Soueraigne,

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: You haue no cause to hold my friendship doubtfull,

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: I neuer was, nor neuer will be false.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Goe then, and muster men: but leaue behind

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your Sonne {% italic: George Stanley: %} looke your heart be firme,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Or else his Heads assurance is but fraile.

lines.speaker: Stan.
lines.text: So deale with him, as I proue true to you.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: My gracious Soueraigne, now in Deuonshire,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: As I by friends am well aduertised,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Edward Courtney %}, and the haughtie Prelate,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Bishop of Exeter, his elder Brother,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: With many moe Confederates, are in Armes.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: In Kent, my Liege, the {% italic: Guilfords %} are in Armes,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: And euery houre more Competitors

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Flocke to the Rebels, and their power growes strong.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: My Lord, the Armie of great {% italic: Buckingham %}.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Out on ye, Owles, nothing but Songs of Death,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: There, take thou that, till thou bring better newes.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: The newes I haue to tell your Maiestie,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Is, that by sudden Floods, and fall of Waters,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: {% italic: Buckinghams %} Armie is dispers'd and scatter'd,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: And he himselfe wandred away alone,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: No man knowes whither.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I cry thee mercie:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: There is my Purse, to cure that Blow of thine.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Hath any well‑aduised friend proclaym'd

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Reward to him that brings the Traytor in?

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Such Proclamation hath been made, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Thomas Louell %}, and Lord Marquesse {% italic: Dorset %},

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: 'Tis said, my Liege, in Yorkeshire are in Armes:

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: But this good comfort bring I to your Highnesse,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: The Brittaine Nauie is dispers'd by Tempest.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: {% italic: Richmond %} in Dorsetshire sent out a Boat

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Vnto the shore, to aske those on the Banks,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: If they were his Assistants, yea, or no?

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Who answer'd him, they came from {% italic: Buckingham %},

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Vpon his partie: he mistrusting them,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Hoys'd sayle, and made his course againe for Brittaine.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: March on, march on, since we are vp in Armes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If not to fight with forraine Enemies,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Yet to beat downe these Rebels here at home.

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: My Liege, the Duke of Buckingham is taken,

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: That is the best newes: that the Earle of Richmond

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: Is with a mighty power Landed at Milford,

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: Is colder Newes, but yet they must be told.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Away towards Salsbury, while we reason here,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A Royall batteil might be wonne and lost:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Some one take order Buckingham be brought

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To Salsbury, the rest march on with me.

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Christopher %}, tell {% italic: Richmond %} this from me,

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: That in the stye of the most deadly Bore,

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: My Sonne {% italic: George Stanley %} is frankt vp in hold:

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: If I reuolt, off goes yong {% italic: Georges %} head,

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: The feare of that, holds off my present ayde.

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: So get thee gone: commend me to thy Lord.

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Withall say, that the Queene hath heartily consented

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: He should espouse {% italic: Elizabeth %} hir daughter.

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: But tell me, where is Princely Richmond now?

lines.speaker: Chri.
lines.text: At Penbroke, or at Hertford West in Wales.

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: What men of Name resort to him.

lines.speaker: Chri,
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Walter Herbert, %} a renowned Souldier,

lines.speaker: Chri,
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Gilbert Talbot %}, Sir {% italic: William Stanley %},

lines.speaker: Chri,
lines.text: {% italic: Oxford %}, redoubted {% italic: Pembroke %}, Sir {% italic: Iames Blunt %},

lines.speaker: Chri,
lines.text: And {% italic: Rice ap Thomas %}, with a valiant Crew,

lines.speaker: Chri,
lines.text: And many other of great name and worth:

lines.speaker: Chri,
lines.text: And towards London do they bend their power,

lines.speaker: Chri,
lines.text: If by the way they be not fought withall.

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Well hye thee to thy Lord: I kisse his hand,

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: My Letter will resolue him of my minde.

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Farewell.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Will not King {% italic: Richard %} let me speake with him?

lines.speaker: Sher.
lines.text: No my good Lord, therefore be patient.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: {% italic: Hastings %}, and {% italic: Edwards %} children, {% italic: Gray %} & {% italic: Riuers %},

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Holy King {% italic: Henry %}, and thy faire Sonne {% italic: Edward %},

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: {% italic: Vaughan %}, and all that haue miscarried

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: By vnder‑hand corrupted foule iniustice,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: If that your moody disconcented soules,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Do through the clowds behold this present houre,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Euen for reuenge mocke my destruction.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: This is All‑soules day (Fellow) is it not?

lines.speaker: Sher.
lines.text: It is.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Why then Al‑soules day, is my bodies doomsday

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: This is the day, which in King {% italic: Edwards %} time

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: I wish'd might fall on me, when I was found

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: False to his Children, and his Wiues Allies.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: This is the day, wherein I wisht to fall

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: By the false Faith of him whom most I trusted.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: This, this All‑soules day to my fearfull Soule,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Is the determin'd respit of my wrongs:

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: That high All‑seer, which I dallied with,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Hath turn'd my fained Prayer on my head,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: And giuen in earnest, what I begg'd in iest.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: To turne their owne points in their Masters bosomes.

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Thus {% italic: Margarets %} curse falles heauy on my necke:

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: When he (quoth she) shall split thy heart with sorrow,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Remember {% italic: Margaret %} was a Prophetesse:

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Come leade me Officers to the blocke of shame,

lines.speaker: Buc.
lines.text: Wrong hath but wrong, and blame the due of blame.

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: Fellowes in Armes, and my most louing Frends

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: Bruis'd vnderneath the yoake of Tyranny,

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: Thus farre into the bowels of the Land,

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: Haue we marcht on without impediment;

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: And heere receiue we from our Father {% italic: Stanley %}

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: Lines of faire comfort and encouragement:

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: The wretched, bloody and vsurping Boare,

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: (That spoyl'd your Summer Fields, and fruitfull Vines)

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: Swilles your warm blood like wash, & makes his trough

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: In your embowel'd bosomes: This foule Swine

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: Is now euen in the Centry of this Isle,

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: Ne're to the Towne of Leicester, as we learne:

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: From Tamworth thither, is but one dayes march.

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: In Gods name cheerely on, couragious Friends,

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: To reape the Haruest of perpetuall peace,

lines.speaker: Richm
lines.text: By this one bloody tryall off sharpe Warre.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Euery mans Conscience is a thousand men,

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: To fight against this guilty Homicide.

lines.speaker: Her.
lines.text: I doubt not but his Friends will turne to vs.

lines.speaker: Blunt.
lines.text: He hath no friends, but what are friends for fear,

lines.speaker: Blunt.
lines.text: Which in his deerest neede will flye from him.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: All for our vantage, then in Gods name march,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: True Hope is swift, and flyes with Swallowes wings,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Kings it makes Gods, and meaner creatures Kings.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Here pitch our Tent, euen here in Bosworth field,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Lord of Surrey, why looke you so sad?

lines.speaker: Sur.
lines.text: My heart is ten times lighter then my lookes.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Lord of Norfolke.

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Heere most gracious Liege.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Norfolke, we must haue knockes:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: We must both giue and take my louing Lord.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vp with my Tent, heere wil I lye to night,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But where to morrow? Well, all's one for that.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Who hath descried the number of the Traitors?

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Six or seuen thousand is their vtmost power.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Why our Battalia trebbles that account:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Besides, the Kings name is a Tower of strength,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which they vpon the aduerse Faction want.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vp with the Tent: Come Noble Gentlemen,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Let vs suruey the vantage of the ground.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Call for some Men of sound direction:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Let's lacke no Discipline, make no delay,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For Lords, to morrow is a busie day.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: The weary Sunne, hath made a Golden set,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: And by the bright Tract of his fiery Carre,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Giues token of a goodly day to morrow.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: William Brandon %}, you shall beare my Standard:

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Giue me some Inke and Paper in my Tent:

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Ile draw the Forme and Modell of our Battaile,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Limit each Leader to his seuerall Charge,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: And part in iust proportion our small Power.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: My Lord of Oxford, you Sir {% italic: William Brandon %},

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: And your Sir {% italic: Walter Herbert %} stay with me:

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: The Earle of Pembroke keepes his Regiment;

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Good Captaine {% italic: Blunt %}, beare my goodnight to him,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: And by the second houre in the Morning,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Desire the Earle to see me in my Tent:

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Yet one thing more (good Captaine) do for me:

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Where is Lord {% italic: Stanley %} quarter'd, do you know ?

lines.speaker: Blunt.
lines.text: Vnlesse I haue mistane his Colours much,

lines.speaker: Blunt.
lines.text: (Which well I am assur'd I haue not done)

lines.speaker: Blunt.
lines.text: His Regiment lies halfe a Mile at least

lines.speaker: Blunt.
lines.text: South, from the mighty Power of the King.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: If without perill it be possible,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Sweet {% italic: Blunt %}, make some good meanes to speak with him

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: And giue him from me, this most needfull Note.

lines.speaker: Blunt.
lines.text: Vpon my life, my Lord, Ile vndertake it,

lines.speaker: Blunt.
lines.text: And so God giue you quiet rest to night.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Good night good Captaine {% italic: Blunt %}:

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Come Gentlemen,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Let vs consult vpon to morrowes Businesse;

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Into my Tent, the Dew is rawe and cold.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What is't a Clocke?

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: It's Supper time my Lord, it's nine a clocke.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I will not sup to night,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Giue me some Inke and Paper:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: What, is my Beauer easier then it was ?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And all my Armour laid into my Tent?

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: It is my Liege: and all things are in readinesse.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Good Norfolke, hye thee to thy charge,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vse carefull Watch, choose trusty Centinels,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: I go my Lord.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Stir with the Larke to morrow, gentle Norfolk.

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: I warrant you my Lord.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Ratcliffe %}.

lines.speaker: Rat.
lines.text: My Lord.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Send out a Pursuiuiant at Armes

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To {% italic: Stanleys %} Regiment: bid him bring his power

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Before Sun‑rising, least his Sonne {% italic: George %} fall

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Into the blinde Caue of eternall night.

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.text: Aduance our Standards, set vpon our Foes,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Our Ancient word of Courage, faire {% italic: George %}

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Inspire vs with the spleene of fiery Dragons:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Vpon them, Victorie sits on our helpes.

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: Rescue my Lord of Norfolke,

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: Rescue, Rescue:

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: The King enacts more wonders then a man,

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: Daring an opposite to euery danger:

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: His horse is slaine, and all on foot he fights,

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death:

lines.speaker: Cat.
lines.text: Rescue faire Lord, or else the day is lost.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A Horse, a Horse, my Kingdome for a Horse.

lines.speaker: Cates.
lines.text: Withdraw my Lord, Ile helpe you to a Horse

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Slaue, I haue set my life vpon a cast,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And I will stand the hazard of the Dye:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I thinke there be sixe Richmonds in the field,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Fiue haue I slaine to day, in stead of him.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A Horse, a Horse, my Kingdome for a Horse.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: God, and your Armes

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Be prais'd Victorious Friends;

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: The day is ours, the bloudy Dogge is dead.

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Couragious Richmond,

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Well hast thou acquit thee: Loe,

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Heere these long vsurped Royalties,

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: From the dead Temples of this bloudy Wretch,

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Haue I pluck'd off, to grace thy Browes withall.

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Weare it, and make much of it.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Great God of Heauen, say Amen to all.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: But tell me, is yong {% italic: George Stanley %} liuing?

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: He is my Lord, and safe in Leicester Towne,

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Whither (if you please) we may withdraw vs.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: What men of name are slaine on either side?

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: {% italic: Iohn %} Duke of Norfolke, {% italic: Walter %} Lord Ferris,

lines.speaker: Der.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Robert Brokenbury %}, and Sir {% italic: William Brandon %}.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Interre their Bodies, as become their Birth,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Proclaime a pardon to the Soldiers fled,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: That in submission will returne to vs,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: And then as we haue tane the Sacrament,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: We will vnite the White Rose, and the Red.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Smile Heauen vpon this faire Coniunction,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: That long haue frown'd vpon their Enmity:

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: What Traitor heares me, and sayes not Amen ?

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: England hath long beene mad, and scarr'd her selfe;

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: The Brother blindely shed the Brothers blood;

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: The Father, rashly slaughtered his owne Sonne;

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: The Sonne compell'd, beene Butcher to the Sire;

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: All this diuided Yorke and Lancaster,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Diuided, in their dire Diuision.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: O now, let {% italic: Richmond %} and {% italic: Elizabeth %},

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: The true Succeeders of each Royall House,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: By Gods faire ordinance, conioyne together:

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: And let thy Heires (God if thy will be so)

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Enrich the time to come, with Smooth‑fac'd Peace,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: With smiling Plenty, and faire Prosperous dayes.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Abate the edge of Traitors, Gracious Lord,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: That would reduce these bloudy dayes againe,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: And make poore England weepe in Streames of Blood;

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Let them not liue to taste this Lands increase,

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: That would with Treason, wound this faire Lands peace.

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: Now Ciuill wounds are stopp'd, Peace liues agen;

lines.speaker: Richm.
lines.text: That she may long liue heere, God say, Amen.
